revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} The '''Bahá'í Faith in Samoa and American Samoa''' begins with the then head of the religion, [[`Abdu'l-Bahá]], mentioning the islands in 1916.{{cite book |author = `Abdu'l–Bahá |authorlink = `Abdu'l-Bahá |year = 1991 |title = Tablets of the Divine Plan |edition = Paperback |publisher = Bahá'í Publishing Trust |location = Wilmette, Illinois, USA |isbn = 0-87743-233-3 |url =http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/ab/TDP/tdp–7.html.iso8859–1?#gr5 |page=40 |origyear = 1916–17}} This inspired Bahá'ís on their way to [[Australia]] in 1920 to stop in [[Samoa]].{{cite encyclopedia | last = Hassall | first = Graham | title = Clara and Hyde Dunn |type=draft article | encyclopedia = A Short Encyclopedia of the Baha'i Faith | publisher = Bahá'í Library Online | date = 9 March 1994 | url = http://bahai-library.com/hassall_clara_hyde_dunn | accessdate = 6 February 2015}} Thirty four years later another Bahá'í from Australia [[Pioneering (Bahá'í)|pioneered]] to Samoa in 1954.{{cite web |author=National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of Samoa |title=50th Anniversary of the Bahá'í Faith in Samoa |work=Waves of One Ocean, Official Bahá'í website |publisher=National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of Samoa |date=February 2004 |url=http://bci.org/bahaisamoa/information.html |accessdate=15 June 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090904043508/http://bci.org/bahaisamoa/information.html |archivedate=4 September 2009 |df=dmy }} With the first converts the first Bahá'í [[Local Spiritual Assembly]] was elected in 1961,{{Cite news | last = International Community | first = Bahá'í | authorlink = Bahá'í International Community | title = Timeline of significant evens in the history of the Bahá'í Faith in Samoa and American Samoa (1954 –2004.) | newspaper = Bahá'í World News Service | date = 30 November 2004 | url = http://news.bahai.org/multimedia/slideshow.php?storyid=337 }} and the Bahá'í [[National Spiritual Assembly]] was first elected in 1970. Following the conversion of the then Head of State of Samoa, [[Malietoa Tanumafili II of Samoa|King Malietoa Tanumafili II]],{{cite book | last = International Community | first = Bahá'í | authorlink = Bahá'í International Community | title = Century of Light | publisher = Bahá'í International Community |date=September 2006 | location = Project Gutenberg | page = 122 | url = http://www.gutenberg.org/files/19267/19267–h/19267–h.html | isbn = }} the first [[Bahá'í House of Worship]] of the Pacific Islands was finished in 1984 and the Bahá'í community reached a population of over 3,000 in about the year 2000.{{cite encyclopedia |title=Samoa Facts and Figures from Encarta – People |encyclopedia=Encarta |volume=Online |publisher=Microsoft |year=2008 |url=http://encarta.msn.com/fact_631504895/samoa_facts_and_figures.html |accessdate=15 June 2008 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5kwPpSkzv?url=http://encarta.msn.com/fact_631504895/samoa_facts_and_figures.html |archivedate=31 October 2009 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} == Early history == {{Bahá'í sidebar}} The first mention of the Samoan Islands in [[Bahá'í literature]] is in a series of letters, or [[tablets (religious)|tablets]], to the followers of the religion in the [[United States]] in 1916–1917 by `Abdu'l–Bahá, head of the religion until 1921 when he died, asking the followers of the religion to travel to other countries; these letters were compiled together in the book titled [[Tablets of the Divine Plan]]. The seventh of the tablets was the first to mention several island nations in the [[Pacific Ocean]]. Written on 11 April 1916, it was delayed in being presented in the United States until 1919 – after the end of [[World War I]] and the [[Spanish flu]]. The seventh tablet was translated and presented by [[Mirza Ahmad Sohrab]] on 4 April 1919, and published in [[Star of the West (Bahá'í magazine)|Star of the West]] magazine on 12 December 1919.{{cite book| last = Abbas | first = `Abdu'l-Bahá |others=Mirza Ahmad Sohrab (trans. and comments) | title = Tablets, Instructions and Words of Explanation |date=April 1919 | url = http://bahai-library.com/abdulbaha_tablets_instructions_explanation}}
"A party speaking their languages, severed, holy, sanctified and filled with the love of God, must turn their faces to and travel through the three great island groups of the Pacific Ocean—[[Polynesia]], [[Micronesia]] and [[Melanesia]], and the islands attached to these groups, such as [[New Guinea]], [[Borneo]], [[Java]], [[Sumatra]], [[Philippine Islands]], [[Solomon Islands]], [[Fiji|Fiji Islands]], [[New Hebrides]], [[Loyalty Islands]], [[New Caledonia]], [[Bismarck Archipelago]], [[Seram Island|Ceram]], [[Sulawesi|Celebes]], [[Friendly Islands]], [[Samoa Islands]], [[Society Islands]], [[Caroline Islands]], [[Low Archipelago]], [[Marquesas]], [[Hawaiian Islands]], [[Gilbert Islands]], [[Moluccas]], [[Marshall Islands]], [[Timor]] and the other islands. With hearts overflowing with the love of God, with tongues commemorating the mention of God, with eyes turned to the Kingdom of God, they must deliver the glad tidings of the manifestation of the Lord of Hosts to all the people."
Following this call to pioneer in 1919, Clara and Hyde Dunn moved from the [[Bahá'í Faith in the United Kingdom|United Kingdom]] to the United States where they met and married and then decided to [[pioneering (Bahá'í)|pioneer]] to Australia in 1920 and stopped briefly in Samoa on their way. [[Shoghi Effendi]], head of the religion after the death of `Abdu'l–Bahá, launched the [[Ten Year Crusade]] and during this plan, 34 years after the first Bahá'ís of Australia had stopped at Samoa, a woman named Lilian Wyss pioneered to Western Samoa{{Cite book | last = Hassall | first = Graham | authorlink = Graham Hassall | editor1-last = Rubinstein | editor1-first = Donald H. | chapter = Pacific Baha'i Communities 1950–1964 | chapterurl = http://bahai-library.com/hassall_bahai_pacific | title = Pacific History: Papers from the 8th Pacific History Association Conference | year = 1992 | pages = 73–95 | place = | publisher = University of Guam Press & Micronesian Area Research Center, Guam | url =http://bahai-library.com}} from Australia in January 1954 leaving behind a position on the National Spiritual Assembly of Australia{{cite web | last = Hassall | first = Graham | authorlink = Graham Hassall | title = Yerrinbool Baha'i School 1938 – 1988 – An Account of the First Fifty Years | work = collections Asia–pacific and Article_published | publisher = Bahá'í Academics Resource Library | year = 1988 | url = http://bahai-library.com/hassall_yerrinbool_1938–1988 | accessdate = 15 June 2008 }} at the age of 24 while her brother, Frank Wyss, introduced the religion that year to the [[Cocos Island]]. For their service, Shoghi Effendi awarded both of them the accolade of [[Knight of Bahá'u'lláh]].{{Cite news | last = International Community | first = Bahá'í | authorlink = Bahá'í International Community | title = Royal welcome at jubilee gathering in Samoa | newspaper = Bahá'í World News Service | date = 30 November 2004 | url = http://news.bahai.org/story/337}} Later she married and took the name Suhayl 'Alá'í.{{cite magazine | title = A ceremony in Samoa |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=June 1979 |pages=3–7 | url = | issue = 542}} About this time Emmanuel Rock, one of the earliest Samoans to join the religion, did so prior to the beginning of the [[Ten Year Crusade]].{{cite magazine | title = Canada tell achievements in Samoa, Iceland|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=May 1956 | page =13 | url = | issue = 303}} Simple [[Bahá'í literature]] was translated into the Samoan language about 1955{{cite magazine | title = World Cruscade; Asia Translations |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=June 1955 | page =12 | url = | issue = 292}} and into the language of [[Niue Island]] in 1956.{{cite magazine | title = International News; Samoan group attains a Crusade Goal|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=June 1956 | page =16 | url = | issue = 304}} At this time Bahá'í sources claim there were five Bahá'ís known among the Samoa Islands.{{cite magazine | title = World Cruscade; Pioneer Letters; Australia and New Zealand |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=December 1955 |pages=4–5 | url = | issue = 298}} The first native believer Mrs. Lotoa Rock, Emmanuel Rock's wife, joined the religion in 1956. In late 1956 Saialala Tamasese was the second native to join the religion{{cite magazine | title = International News; Samoa welcomes second native believer |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=January 1957 | page =6 | url = | issue = 311}} and the first Bahá'í [[Local Spiritual Assembly]] was elected in 1957 in Western Samoa{{cite magazine | title = International News; First Assembly formed in Samoa |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=May 1958 | page =18 | url = | issue = 327}} with another five smaller groups of Bahá'ís,{{cite magazine | title = International News; First Local Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of Apia |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=May 1958 | page =5 | url = | issue = 321}} followed by an assembly election in Samoa in 1961. Many of the early Bahá'ís were well educated and some had Christian theological training and after conversion sometimes held positions of high office in the religion.{{cite journal | last = Hassall | first = Graham | authorlink = Graham Hassall | title = Baha'i Faith in the Asia Pacific – Issues and Prospects | journal = Bahá'í Studies Review | volume = 6 | publisher = Association for Baha'i Studies (English–Speaking Europe) | location = | year = 1996 | url = http://bahai-library.com/hassall_bahai_asia–pacific_issues | accessdate = 15 June 2008 }} == Developing community == === Connections to and from the Bahá'ís === From then events have multiplied involving the growing community. Starting on 29 October 1958 the first visit of a [[Hand of the Cause]] in the person of [[Enoch Olinga]] began an extended tour of the islands during which Olinga was honored with a [[Kava culture|Kava]] based ceremony.{{cite magazine | title = First Visit of a Hand of the Cause to Fiji and Samoa Islands Brings Great Bounty to Baha'is and Warm Public Reception |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=February 1959 |pages=2–4 | url = | issue = 336}} In 1959 the Bahá'ís gathered in the first summer school with some 30 attendees and hosted by a local chief,{{cite magazine | title = Native Chief is Host to First Baha'i Summer School in Samoa|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=April 1959 | page =8 | url = | issue = 338}} purchased the first Bahá'í cemetery,{{cite magazine | title = Baha'i Burial Ground Purchased in Western Samoa|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=November 1959 | page =15 | url = | issue = 345}} and gathered with Samoans from both islands to consult on the growth of the religion on the islands.{{cite magazine | title = First Samoan Islands Teaching Conference Formulates Four–Year Plan for Spread of Faith|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=February 1960 |pages=3–4 | url = | issue = 348}} In 1962 the religion had reached the island of [[Savai'i]] and the first public talk on the religion was given in Apia – which was extended to three additional talks{{cite magazine | title = Upsurge of Teaching in the South Pacific |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=December 1962 |pages=10–11 | url = | issue = 381}} and Hand of the Cause [[Collis Featherstone]] visited Bahá'ís and civic leaders.{{cite magazine | title = Samoan Teaching Work Goes Forward |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=January 1963 | page =4 | url = | issue = 382}} In 1963 the assembly of [[Pago Pago]] arranged the first observance of [[United Nations Day]] which had the acting governor and other leading figures giving talks. Coverage of the event was carried by print, radio and television media leading up to the event in general and of the Bahá'ís hosting.{{cite magazine | title = First UN Day Observance Ever Held in American Samoa Sponsored by Baha'is |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=January 1964 | page =7 | url = | issue = 394}} In 1964 a conference on Fiji which included Bahá'ís from Tonga, Samoa, New Guinea and Fiji. Immediately following the first convention was held to elect the regional national assembly of South Pacific Ocean.{{cite magazine | title = Teaching Conference Precedes First National Convention of the Baha'is of the South Pacific Ocean|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=September 1964 | page =8 | url = | issue = 402}} Bahá'ís continued to come and began to leave from Samoa. Also in 1965 the first Samoan [[Pioneering (Bahá'í)|pioneer]] returned to the island of his birth – the [[Tokelau Islands]].{{cite magazine | title = South Pacific Delegates Assemble in Tonga |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=January 1966 |pages=10–11 | url = | issue = 426}} It was three years before authorities allowed him to promulgate his religion.{{cite magazine | title = Women Take Leading Role in South Pacific Islands |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=November 1969 | page =12 | url = | issue = 426}} Samoan Auxiliary Board member Niuoleava Tuataga toured Australia giving talks to Bahá'ís and Australian society on the religion in 1967.{{cite magazine | title = Samoan Board Member Visits Australian States|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=April 1968 | page =11 | url = | issue = 445}} [[Russell Garcia (composer)|Russell Garcia]] and Gina, his wife, visited many islands among Samoa in 1967 and others giving concerts and classes in schools for several years{{cite magazine | title = A Teaching Trip to Samoa |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=January 1971 | page =6 | url = | issue = 478}} before ultimately moving to New Zealand. In 1969 Samoan Bahá'í women stretched social norms by personally taking trips to attempt to spread the religion. From December 1969 into January 1970 the first international youth conference of the south pacific took place in Apia drawing attendees from Samoa. Australia, Fiji, Hawaii, New Caledonia, New Zealand, Tonga, United States, and Western Samoa. Hand of the Cause [[Abu'l-Qásim Faizi]] attended and gave talks both to the attendees and to the public afterwards.{{cite magazine | title = Western Samoa Youth Conference|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=March 1970 | page =15 | url = | issue = 468}} In 1970 the [[National Spiritual Assembly]] of the Bahá'ís of Samoa was elected at a convention hosting Hand of the Cause of God Collis Featherstone, Continental Board of Counsellors member Suhayl Ala'i, Auxiliary Board member Niuoleava Tuataga, the nine delegates and over fifty members of the religion from both Western and American Samoa. The elected members of the national assembly were from both Western and American Samoa.{{cite magazine | title = First National Convention Samoa|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=August 1970 | page =8 | url = | issue = 473}} === Contact with civilian leaders === In an event that would have long range effects on the community in 1965 Tamasese, one of the first native Bahá'ís of Samoa, died and at the funeral members of a royal family of Samoa were present at the Bahá'í funeral.{{cite magazine | title = Funeral of First Samoan Believer Becomes Public Proclamation of Faith |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=January 1966 | page =3 | url = | issue = 418}} According to tradition, a fine mat is presented to the presiding officer of the funeral which in this case was an [[Bahá'í administration#Auxiliary Boards|Auxiliary Board member]]. This mat was presented to the [[Universal House of Justice]] in 1968.{{cite magazine | title = Fine Mat Presented to Universal House of Justice |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=January 1968 | page =2 | url = | issue = 442}} This same mat was gifted to the King at the dedication of the temple in 1979. Meanwhile, cooperation with the government of Samoa expanded. In 1967 Bahá'ís presented [[Bahá'í literature]] to the kings of Tonga and Samoa with more planned for leaders of government.{{cite magazine | title = Great Distances Bridged by Power of the Faith; Prodamation Books to be Presented |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=December 1967 |pages=39–40 | url = | issue = 426}} In 1967 the government of Samoa sponsored the observance of United Nations Day. In years past it had been the Baha'i community of American Samoa that had sponsored the observance, with the aid of the government of American Samoa. This year [[List of governors of American Samoa|Governor Aspinall]] appointed a United Nations Day Committee which included the chairman of the National Spiritual Assembly of the South Pacific Ocean, Suhayl Ala'i, as member of the Committee for Iran. Mr. Ala'i made suggestions resulting in the inclusion of the Baha'i prayer for unity in the program and the committee secured the services of Hand of the Cause Ugo Giachery as guest speaker.{{cite magazine | title = Samoan Acting Governor Introduces Baha'i Speaker |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=January 1968 | page =17 | url = | issue = 442}} By 1968 King [[Malietoa Tanumafili II]] of Samoa privately converted to the religion and announced it publicly in 1973 when he wrote a letter to the convention to elect the Universal House of Justice.{{cite magazine | title = Universal House Announces Crowning Victory|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=July 1973 | page =3 | url = | issue = 478}} The Universal House of Justice asked Bahá'ís individually to not seek publicity of the issue at the time. In 1974 King Malietoa Tanumafili II attended the national convention and congratulated work on construction of a Bahá'í center and [[KVZK-2]] recorded a series of three 15-minute programs to be broadcast as part of its daily show ''Talosaga''.{{cite magazine | title = Around the World; Western Samoa; Head of State visits Convention|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=August 1974 |pages=1–2 | url = | issue = 521}} In 1976 the national assembly was registered with the United States, the first Bahá'í center on [[Tutuila]] was raised,{{cite magazine | title = Around the World; Samoa; Center is dedicated on island of Tutuila|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=June 1976 | page =12 | url = | issue = 543}} and King Tanumafili visited the grave of [[Shoghi Effendi]].{{cite magazine | title = Royalty visits Guardian's resting place |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=October 1976 | page =1 | url = | issue = 547}} In 1986 as part of a series of events (see below) highlighting the importance of peace the Bahá'ís had meetings with the American Samoan Speaker of the House and the prime minister of Western Samoa attended including a presentation of the statement by the [[Universal House of Justice]] called ''[[The Promise of World Peace]]''.{{cite magazine | title = The World; Samoa|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=June 1987 | issn=0195-9212 | page =16| url = | issue = 638}} In 1987 the Bahá'ís helped celebrate the 25th anniversary of the independence of Western Samoa with a commemoration at the Bahá'í House of Worship which included a surprise unveiling of a large portrait of king Tanumafili,{{cite magazine | title = Western Samoa; Portrait of the Malietoais unveiled|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=September 1987 | issn=0195-9212 | page =17| url = | issue = 678}} and at a parade for the anniversary Bahá'ís won third place in a contest of floats.{{cite magazine | title = The World; Samoa|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=January 1988 | issn=0195-9212 | page =17| url = | issue = 682}} At the 27th anniversary Bahá'ís double purposed the celebration with a service dedicated to World Environment Day which was followed by talks by Bahá'ís and head of the Forestry Division of the federal Environmental Program and Tafaese Lautua, a member of Parliament, also thanked the Bahá'ís on behalf of the minister of Lands and Survey/Park Preservation.{{cite magazine | title = The World; Samoa|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=September 1989 | issn=0195-9212 | page =13| url = | issue = 701}} At the 50th anniversary of the reign of king Tanumafili II a parade in which 40 Baha'is marched for the review of the Malietoa and his guest, the king of Tonga as well as entered a float in a parade depicting the oneness of mankind, which placed second in the judging. The float held the grandson of the king who is also a Bahá'í.{{cite magazine | title = The World; Samoa|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=July 1990 | issn=0195-9212 | page =15| url = | issue = 711}} === Organization and growth === In 1977 three summer schools were held in Samoa, one in each of the major islands of Savai'i, Tutuila and Upolu, replacing the usual central summer school held in Lelata, Apia, and the same year the first national children's conference took place.{{cite magazine | title = Around the World; Samoa; Minister supports Faith|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=August 1978 | page =12 | url = | issue = 569}} At that time eight of ten planned local centers had been built and there were at least 24 local assemblies.{{cite magazine | title = Around the World; Summer schools are tripled|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=June 1977 | page =15 | url = | issue = 555}} In 1978 the annual convention had 30 delegates to elect the national assembly – and the elected members of that year were Sam Ale Ale, Moli Chang, Reuben Busby, Lilian Ala'i, Fuiono Aniseto, Lina Kava, Khosrow Moghelpour, Fili Pe'epe'e and Leala Tasi.{{cite magazine | title = Around the World; Samoa; National Convention|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=October 1978 | page =17 | url = | issue = 571}} In 1978 an award was given to Bahá'í youth and children who took part in the Samoan Arts Festival; following [[Bahá'í laws]] the money award was donated to a humanitarian agency.{{cite magazine | title = Around the World; Samoa; National Convention|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=February 1979 | page =16 | url = | issue = 575}} In 1979 the Bahá'ís of Samoa in cooperation with Russ and Gina Garcia produced a film commemorating the [[International Year of the Child]] that was shown on television several times in Samoa.{{cite magazine | title = Around the World; Samoa|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=July 1980 |pages=16–17 | url = | issue = 592}} In 1981 one hundred fifty people from Samoa, Tuvalu, the Cook Islands, Kiribati, New Zealand and the United States attended a women's conference in Samoa that was planned to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the death of [[Bahiyyih Khánum]].{{cite magazine | title = Around the World; Samoa|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=November 1982 | issn=0195-9212 | page =16| url = | issue = 620}} Speakers included the wife and sister of the king of Samoa, and the wife of the prime minister of the Cook Islands and a Maori woman from New Zealand.{{cite magazine | title = Around the World; Samoa|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=May 1983 | issn=0195-9212 | page =12| url = | issue = 626}} === Coordinated efforts === Since its inception the religion has had involvement in [[Socio-economic development (Bahá'í)|socio–economic development]] beginning by giving greater freedom to women,{{cite encyclopedia | last = Momen | first = Moojan | title = History of the Baha'i Faith in Iran | encyclopedia = A Short Encyclopedia of the Baha'i Faith |type=draft article | publisher = bahai-library.com | url = http://bahai-library.com/momen_encyclopedia_iran#9.%20Social%20and%20economic%20development | doi = | accessdate = 16 October 2009}} promulgating the promotion of female education as a priority concern,{{cite journal | last = Kingdon | first = Geeta Gandhi | title = Education of women and socio–economic development | journal = Baha'i Studies Review | volume = 7 | issue = 1 | year = 1997 | url =http://bahai-library.com/kingdon_education_women_development }} and that involvement was given practical expression by creating schools, agricultural coops, and clinics. The religion entered a new phase of activity when a message of the [[Universal House of Justice]] dated 20 October 1983 was released.{{cite journal |title= The Baha'i Faith 1957–1988: A Survey of Contemporary Developments | first = Moojan | last = Momen |author2=Smith, Peter | year = 1989 | url = http://bahai-library.com/momen_smith_developments_1957–1988 |volume = 19 | journal = Religion | pages=63–91 |doi= 10.1016/0048-721X(89)90077-8}} Bahá'ís were urged to seek out ways, compatible with the [[Bahá'í teachings]], in which they could become involved in the social and economic development of the communities in which they lived. World–wide in 1979 there were 129 officially recognized Bahá'í socio–economic development projects. In 1983 the national assembly sponsored a conference on rural development for one hundred–ten people from Upolu, Savaii and Tutuila, at Lelata.{{cite magazine | title = Around the World; Samoa|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=May 1984 | issn=0195-9212 | page =16| url = | issue = 638}} In 1986, in addition to an observance held at the Bahá'í House of Worship, (see below), the Bahá'ís sponsored a peace essay contest where Certificates of recognition were given to each of 36 finalists and monetary prizes awarded to seven winners. At the ceremony, Lt. Governor Faleomavaega Eni Hunkin and Counsellor Suhayl Ala'i spoke about peace. The Bahá'ís also held a conference on Family Welfare and Management with a talk by Western Samoa's assistant secretary for the Ministry of Youth, Sports and Culture, and other talks with 200 Baha'is in attendance.{{cite magazine | title = Special report; The International Year of Peace; Samoa|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=September 1987 | issn=0195-9212 | page =11| url = | issue = 638}} By 1987 worldwide the number of officially recognized development projects had increased to 1482. Samoan Bahá'í youth began to be noticed in the development of the community – three youth were sponsored in 1985 for the [[International Youth Year]] and participated in [[United Nations]] and international projects.{{cite web| last = Bahá'í International Community | first = | title = Report of Bahá'í International Community activities in support of the United Nations International Youth Year | work = Statement and Reports of the Bahá'í International Community | publisher = Bahá'í International Community | date = 3 June 1986 | url = http://www.bic.org/statements–and–reports/bic–statements/86–0603.htm | doi = | accessdate = 19 November 2008}} By the 1990s there were Samoan youth workshops (see [[Oscar DeGruy]]) performing internationally. === Bahá'í House of Worship === The site of the future temple was celebrated in 1976 with a gathering of over one hundred Bahá'ís and children who sang songs and said prayers for four days.{{cite magazine | title = Around the World; Samoa; Prayers are said at Temple site |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=May 1976 | page =13 | url = | issue = 542}} Twenty five years after the first Bahá'í settled in the islands of Samoa the [[Bahá'í House of Worship]] in [[Tiapapata]], 8 km from [[Apia, Samoa]], had its cornerstone set in 1979 and was completed in 1984 and serves as the Mother Temple of the Pacific Islands. After three days of celebrations and talks the cornerstone was laid and the Temple later dedicated by King Malietoa Tanumafili II of Samoa who was the first reigning Bahá'í [[monarch]]. [[Hand of the Cause]] [[Rúhíyyih Khanum]] was also present at the laying of the cornerstone and its dedication. More than 500 Bahá'ís attended at the laying of the cornerstone and guests included members of the family of the king; representatives of 16 national assemblies; heads of several departments of the Samoan government and representatives of the churches of Samoa. At the dedication more than 1,000 Bahá'ís from 45 countries and islands with civic leaders including the king and prime minister and other officials.{{cite magazine | title = Samoa; Photographs of Temple's dedication |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=November 1984 | issn=0195-9212|pages=1–3| url = | issue = 644}} The structure is completely open to the island breezes.[http://www.bahaitemplesamoa.org/History.htm Statement on the History of the Bahá'í Temple of Samoa] The lands of the Temple are also the resting place of [[Hand of the Cause]] [[Ugo Giachery]].{{cite web | last = Brogan | first = Todd | title = Baha'i House of Worship, Apia | work = SAMOA | publisher = Sacred Destinations | year = 2008 | url = http://www.sacred–destinations.com/samoa/apia–bahai–temple.htm | accessdate = 15 June 2008}} Perhaps the first large event held at the temple was a special service in 1985 to commemorate the 40th anniversary of the United Nations and to launch the UN [[International observance#1980s|International Year of Peace]].{{cite magazine | title = Around the World; Samoa |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=September 1986 | issn=0195-9212| page =14| url = | issue = 666}} Among the guests at the service were the king and members of his family including Princess Tooa Salamasina Malietoa; the New Zealand High Commissioner; the Chinese ambassador; consuls from France, the Netherlands, and the United States; and other diplomatic dignitaries. The UN's resident Representative was present, as was the UNESCO Representative and most of the UN personnel in Samoa. Some of the dependencies of a Bahá'í House of Worship have also been developed — – a cemetery and school have been set. == Modern community == Across Samoa and American Samoa there are Bahá'í communities in Puleia, Papa–i–Palauli–le–Falefa, Sasina, Pu'apu'a, Faleasi'u–Uta, Faeasi'u–Tai, Laleta, Lepea, [[Pago Pago]], Iliili, [[Tafuna]], and [[Leone, American Samoa|Leone]]. The Bahá'ís of Samoa numbered too few to show up in the 2001 national census.{{cite web | url = https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71356.htm | title = International Religious Freedom Report – Samoa | date = 15 September 2006 | accessdate = 15 June 2008 | author = Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor | publisher = United States State Department}}{{cite web | url = https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2007/90152.htm | title = International Religious Freedom Report – Samoa | date = 14 September 2007 | accessdate = 15 June 2008 | author = Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor | publisher = United States State Department}} The shared estimate of the Bahá'í population in Samoa circa 2000 according to a profile by the [[World Council of Churches]] and the online encyclopedia [[Encarta]] was 2% of the nation – some 3600 people – and the only non–Christian community of any number.{{cite web | title = Samoa | work = WCC > Member churches > Regions > Pacific > | publisher = World Council of Churches | date = 1 January 2006 | url = http://www.oikoumene.org/en/member–churches/regions/pacific/samoa.html | accessdate = 15 June 2008}} There are, however, some reports of oppression of the community. The Samoan Bahá'í Charitable Trust for Social and Economic Development was established in 1990 and produced Samoa's first television series dedicated to a healthy diet, "O le Kuka Samoa," on 16 October 2000 with Samoan comedian Sumeo, alias "O le King Kuka," and was aimed at rejuvenating Samoan cultural food practices to help provide better nutrition as well as reliance on local resources.[http://www.sungo.ws/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=73&Itemid=150 Baha’i Charitable Trust] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304000108/http://www.sungo.ws/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=73&Itemid=150 |date=4 March 2016 }}, by Sungo Ilo, 20 September 2011{{Cite news | last = International Community | first = Bahá'í | authorlink = Bahá'í International Community | title = Humor key ingredient in Samoan healthy cooking TV series | newspaper = Bahá'í World News Service | date = 18 October 2000 | url = http://news.bahai.org/story/70}}{{cite web |title=O Le Kuka Samoa (Samoa) |work=Partners for Prosperity Projects |publisher=Partners for Prosperity |url=http://www.partnersforprosperity.org/projects.php?moreinfo=53 |accessdate=15 June 2008 }}{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The Bahá'í community also maintains five Bahá'í pre–schools across all the islands of Samoa,{{cite web |title=The Samoa project – Pre–schools on Samoan Islands |work=Projects |publisher=Baha'i Agency for Social and Economic Development, UK |url=http://www.baseduk.org.uk/project_samoa.htm |accessdate=15 June 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080905180746/http://www.baseduk.org.uk/project_samoa.htm |archivedate=5 September 2008 |df=dmy }} gains converts,{{Cite news | title = Study Circle Group in Samoa | periodical = Bahá'í Journal of the Bahá'í Community of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland | volume = 18 | issue = 1 | date = May 2001 | url = http://bahai-library.com/pdf/bjuk/bjuk_2001_v18_no1-may_5_Committee_for_International_Pioneering_and_Travel_Teaching.pdf}} attracts skilled professionals,{{cite web |author=National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of Australia |title=Penny Taylor: Lawyer attracted to deeds, not words |work=Who We Are |publisher=National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of Australia |url=http://www.bahai.org.au/scripts/WebObjects.exe/BNO.woa/wa/pages?page=who_we_are/profiles/penny_taylor.html |doi= |accessdate=15 June 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080719215729/http://www.bahai.org.au/scripts/WebObjects.exe/BNO.woa/wa/pages?page=who_we_are%2Fprofiles%2Fpenny_taylor.html |archivedate=19 July 2008 |df=dmy }} and a national youth committee is coordinating volunteer youth to come and serve in the Samoan Bahá'í community.{{cite journal | title = Pearl of the Pacific | work = HD Features – Archives | publisher = Australian National Bahá'í Youth Committee |date=March 2006 | url =}} === 50th Anniversary === Representatives of the National Assemblies of Australia, the [[Cook Islands]], [[Fiji]], [[Hawaii]], [[New Zealand]], and [[Tonga]] as well as other dignitaries of the religion and Bahá'ís from the islands of Savai'i and [[Upolu]] and Bahá'í members of the royal family – King Malietoa Tanumafili II of Samoa and daughter Susuga To'oa Tosi Malietoa – attended the celebration of the 50th anniversary of the Bahá'ís Faith in Samoa in 2004 along with various members of the government of Samoa who highlighted many of the services the Bahá'ís have given to the general community. === Head of State Malietoa Tanumafili II of Samoa === On the passing of Head of State Malietoa Tanumafili II of Samoa in 2007, the international governing body of the Bahá'ís, the [[Universal House of Justice]] wrote: "His service to the people of Samoa as Head of State was distinguished by the high principles, genuine compassion and personal humility that characterized the constancy of his concern for the welfare of all. As the first reigning sovereign to accept the Message of [[Bahá'u'lláh]], he set a record that will forever illumine the annals of our Faith, one that future generations will increasingly extol. His great interest for well–nigh four decades in the Faith's progress was reflected in the enthusiastic affirmation of his belief whenever the opportunity presented itself and in the abiding joy with which he regarded the construction in 1984 of the [[Bahá'í House of Worship#Tiapapata, Samoa|Mother Temple of the Pacific Islands]] in Samoa...."{{cite news | title = Funeral and memorial service planned for Samoan head of state | url = http://news.bahai.org/story/543 | work = Bahá'í World News Service | author = Bahá'í International Community | date = 14 May 2007 | accessdate = 15 June 2008}} == See also == * [[History of Samoa]] * [[History of American Samoa]] * [[Religion in Samoa]] == References == {{reflist|2}} == External links == * [http://www.bahai.org/worldwide–community/national–communities/samoa/ Official Website of the National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of Samoa] * [http://bahaisamoa.ws Official Website of the Temple] * [http://www.sacred–destinations.com/samoa/apia–bahai–temple.htm More information on the Temple and its history] {{Oceania topic|Bahá'í Faith in}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Baha'i Faith In American Samoa And Samoa}} [[Category:Bahá'í Faith in American Samoa and Samoa|S]]

:''For the Peripatetic philosopher from Sidon, (c. 75 – c. 10 BC), see [[Boethus of Sidon]]'' '''Boethus''' ({{lang-grc-gre|Βοηθός}}; fl. 2nd century BC) was a [[Stoicism|Stoic]] philosopher from [[Sidon]], and a pupil of [[Diogenes of Babylon]].
He is said to have denied, contrary to the standard Stoic view, that the [[cosmos]] is an animate being,<ref>Diogenes Laërtius, vii. 143</ref> and he suggested that it was not the whole world which was divine, but only the ether or sphere of the fixed stars.<ref name="laertius148">[[Diogenes Laërtius]], vii. 148</ref> He argued that the world was eternal,<ref>[[Philo]], ''De aeternitate mundi'' 76–77</ref> in particular, he rejected the Stoic conflagration (''[[ekpyrosis]]'') because god or the World-Soul would be inactive during it, whereas it exercises [[Divine Providence]] in the actual world.
Among his works was one ''On Nature'',<ref name="laertius148"/> and one ''On Fate''.<ref>Diogenes Laërtius, vii. 149</ref> He wrote a commentary on the works of [[Aratus]] in at least four volumes.<ref>[[Geminus]], xvii 48</ref>

'''Camulodunum''' ({{IPAc-en|ˌ|k|æ|m|j|ʊ|l|əʊ|ˈ|dj|uː|n|ə|m|,_|ˌ|k|æ|m|ʊ|l|əʊ|ˈ|d|uː|n|ə|m}};<ref name="Collins3">{{cite web|url=http://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/camulodunum?showCookiePolicy=true|title=Camulodunum |accessdate=26 September 2014|publisher=Collins Dictionary|date=n.d.}}</ref> {{lang-la|{{sc|camvlodvnvm}}}}), the [[Roman Empire|Ancient Roman]] name for what is now [[Colchester]] in [[Essex]], was an important<ref name="Todd, M 1981"/><ref name="Wilson, Roger J 2002"/> town in [[Roman Britain]], and the first capital of the province. It is claimed to be the [[oldest town in Britain]].<ref name="McWhirr, Alan 1988">McWhirr, Alan (1988) Roman Crafts and Industries. Published by Shire Publications LTD. ({{ISBN|0 85263 594 X}})</ref> Originally the site of the Brythonic-[[Celt]]ic [[oppidum]] of '''Camulodunon''' (meaning "stronghold of [[Camulos]]"), capital of the [[Trinovantes]] and later the [[Catuvellauni]] tribes, it was first mentioned by name on coinage minted by the chieftain [[Tasciovanus]] sometime between 20 and 10 BC.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> The Roman town began life as a [[Castra|Roman Legionary base]] constructed in the AD 40s on the site of the Brythonic-Celtic fortress following its conquest by the Emperor [[Claudius]].<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> After the early town was destroyed during the [[Boudica|Iceni rebellion]] in 60/1 AD, it was rebuilt, reaching its zenith in the 2nd and 3rd centuries.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> During this time it was known by its official name '''Colonia Claudia Victricensis''' (''{{lang|la|{{sc|colonia clavdia victricensis}}}}''),<ref name="BBC">{{cite web |title=Roman Colchester: Britain's First City |author=Mike Ibeji |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/ancient/romans/colchester_04.shtml |publisher=BBC Online |accessdate=20 May 2008}}</ref> often shortened to '''Colonia Victricensis''', and as ''Camulodunum'', a Latinised version of its original Brythonic name.<ref name="cooper"/> The town was home to a large classical [[Temple of Claudius, Colchester|Temple]], two theatres (including Britain's largest), several Romano-British temples, Britain's only known chariot circus, Britain's first town walls, several large cemeteries and over 50 known mosaics and tessellated pavements.<ref name="Todd, M 1981"/><ref name="Wilson, Roger J 2002"/><ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/><ref>Hull, M.R. (1958). Roman Colchester. The Society of Antiquaries of London</ref> It may have reached a population of 30,000 at its height.<ref name="google">{{cite book|title=Discovering Roman Britain|author1=McCloy, A.|author2=Midgley, A.|date=2008|publisher=New Holland|isbn=9781847731289|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mswynZFMtqgC|page=60|accessdate=25 October 2014}}</ref> It was not until the late 18th century that historians realised that Colchester's physical Brythonic (British Celtic) and Roman remains were the city mentioned in ancient literature as "Camulodunum".<ref name="Arthur"/>
==Iron Age ''Camulodunon''== [[File:Camulodunon001.png|right|thumb|The Iron Age site of Camulodunon]] The earliest [[Iron Age Britain|Iron Age]] defensive site at Colchester is the Pitchbury Ramparts earthwork north of the town between West Bergholt and Great Horkesley.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> The main earthwork defences of the Brythonic Celtic [[oppidum]] of ''Camulodunon'' were built later, beginning in the 1st century BC but most date from the 1st century AD.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> They are considered the most extensive of their kind in Britain.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/><ref>http://www.thecolchesterarchaeologist.co.uk/?p=967 retrieved 25 July 2014</ref> The defences consist of lines of ditches and ramparts, possibly palisaded with gateways, that mostly run parallel to each other in a north-south direction. The Iron Age settlement was protected by rivers on three sides, with the [[River Colne, Essex|River Colne]] bounding the site to the north and east, and the Roman River valley forming the southern boundary; the earthworks were mostly designed to close off the western gap between these two river valleys.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/><ref name="Denney, Patrick 2004">Denney, Patrick (2004) Colchester. Published by Tempus Publishing ({{ISBN|978-0-7524-3214-4}})</ref> Other earthworks close off eastern parts of the settlement. These earthworks gave the oppidum its Brythonic Celtic name - ''Camulodunon'' meant "The Stronghold of [[Camulus]]", the British God of War.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> Together they enclose an area of 1,000ha, much larger than the area enclosed by the [[Devil's Dyke, Hertfordshire|Iron Age defences]] at [[Wheathampstead]] (35ha).<ref name="ColchArch2009">The Colchester Archaeologist. Issue no. 22. (2009). (ISSN 0952-0988)</ref>
The main sites within the bounds of these defences are the Gosbecks farmstead, the Sheepen industrial area and the Lexden burials. The Gosbecks site consists of a large, high-status farmstead,<ref name="cooper"/> believed to be the home of the tribal chieftains of Camulodunon.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> Part of the Gosbecks complex is a large, square enclosure surrounded by a deep, wide ditch. This has been interpreted as part of a possible religious site, as during the Roman period a large temple was built in the middle of this enclosure.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> The Sheepen site, located around what is now [[St Helena School, Colchester|St Helena School]] on the banks of the River Colne, was a large industrial and port zone, where extensive iron and leather working activity was carried out,<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/><ref name="Denney, Patrick 2004"/><ref name="roman-britain.org">http://www.roman-britain.org/places/camulodunum.htm retrieved 21 July 2014</ref> as well as an important coin mint.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> Two coins minted at Sheepen, one found in Colchester in 1980 and another found at [[Canturbury]] in 1978, depict boats, and are the only known depictions of sailing vessels from [[Iron Age Britain]].<ref name="Denney, Patrick 2004"/> [[Amphorae]] containing imported goods from the continent have been found at Sheepen,<ref>Sealy, P.R. (1985) Amphoras from the 1970 excavations of Colchester Sheepen. Oxford, British Archaeological Report 142</ref> as have pieces of imported Samian pottery.<ref>Begley, Vimala and Daniel de Puma, Richard (eds.) (1991) Rome and India. The Ancient Sea Trade. Published by The University of Wisconsin Press ({{ISBN|0-299-12640-4}})</ref> [[File:Trinovantes 2.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Coin of the [[Trinovantes]] minted at [[Camulodunon]].]] Just inside the earthworks, at Lexden, are located the burial mounds of the rulers of Camulodunon, which contain large amounts of grave goods including imported Roman material from Europe;<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> the largest of these mounds is the [[Lexden#History|Lexden tumulus]].<ref>{{PastScape|mnumber=384037|mname=|accessdate=22 July 2014}}</ref><ref>http://unlockingessex.essexcc.gov.uk/uep/custom_pages/monument_detail.asp?content_page_id=89&monument_id=34083&content_parents=48 retrieved 22 July 2014</ref> The Lexden area around the mounds contains several Iron Age cremation burial groups, including one containing the "Mirror burial", with other burials located around the Camulodunon site.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> A large cluster of cremations from St. Clares road and Fitzwalter Road close to the Lexden Tumulus date to 50-10 BC.<ref name="ColchArch2009"/>
Aside from these main activity areas, the 1,000ha area enclosed by the defensive earthworks and rivers mainly consisted of a network of droveways, [[hollow way]]s, pastures and fields associated with cattle herding.<ref name="ColchArch2009"/> Scattered [[Roundhouse (dwelling)#British Isles|Roundhouses]] and burials have been discovered amongst these droveways.<ref name="ColchArch2009"/> The defences were designed to protect the high status and industrial areas as well as prevent [[cattle rustling]] of valuable herds.<ref name="ColchArch2009"/> Camulodunon was surrounded by farmsteads like those at Abbotstone near [[Colchester Zoo]] and at [[Birch, Essex|Birch Quarry]], many of which continued to exist on into the Roman period until at least the 2nd and 3rd centuries AD.<ref name="ColchArch2009"/>
Iron Age salt works (known as [[Red Hill (salt making)|Red hills]]) have been found in large numbers around the Essex coast, including several large concentrations located in the [[salt marshes]] close to Camulodunon in the Colne Estuary, on the Roman River near [[Fingringhoe]], in [[Alresford, Essex|Alresford Creek]], on [[Mersea Island]], the Pyefleet Channel, the [[River Blackwater, Essex|Blackwater River]] and around the [[Tendring District|Tendring]] Peninsula.<ref name="Fawn, A 1990"/> Two large groups existed at [[Peldon]] and [[Tolleshunt D'Arcy]].<ref name="Strachan, David 1998">Strachan, David (1998) Essex from the Air, Archaeology and history from aerial photographs. Published by Essex County Council ({{ISBN|1 85281 165 X}})</ref> Camulodunon may have been an at the centre of the local trade in this important preservative.<ref name="Fawn, A 1990"/>
[[File:Bronze coins of Cunobelin 1 to 42 CE.jpg|left|thumb|Bronze coin of Cunobelin - note the letters '''CAMV''' for ''Camulodunon'']] [[Addedomarus]], a king of the [[Trinovantes|Trinovantes tribe]] (originally centred at [[Braughing]]), is the first identifiable ruler of Camulodunon, known from his inscribed coins dating to around 25-10 BC. For a brief period around 10 BC [[Tasciovanus]], a king of the [[Catuvellauni]] already issuing coins from [[Verlamion]], also [[Brythonic coinage|issued coins from Camulodunon]], suggesting that the Trinovantes' capital had been conquered by the Catuvellauni, but he was soon forced to withdraw, perhaps as a result of Roman pressure – his later coins are no longer marked with the Latin ''[[Rex (king)|REX]]'' (for "king"), but with the [[Common Brittonic|Brythonic]] ''RICON'' – and Addedomarus was restored. His son [[Dubnovellaunus]] succeeded him, but was soon supplanted by Tasciovanus' son [[Cunobelinus]]. Cunobelinus then succeeded his father at Verlamion, beginning the dominance of the Catuvellauni over the south-east.<ref>John Creighton (2000), ''Coins and power in Late Iron Age Britain'', Cambridge University Press</ref><ref>[[Philip de Jersey]] (1996), Celtic Coinage in Britain, Shire Archaeology</ref> Cunobelinus was friendly with Rome, marking his coins with the word ''REX'' and classical motifs rather than the traditional Gallo-Belgic designs. Archaeology shows an increase in imported luxury goods, probably through the Sheepen site port of Camulodunon, during his reign.<ref>Keith Branigan (1987), ''The Catuvellauni'', Alan Sutton Publishing Ltd, pp. 10-11</ref> He was probably one of the British kings that [[Strabo]] says sent embassies to [[Augustus]]. Strabo reports Rome's lucrative trade with Britain; the island's exports included grain, gold, silver, iron, hides, slaves and hunting dogs.<ref>[[Strabo]], [http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/Strabo/4E*.html ''Geography'' 4.5]</ref> Iron ingots, slave chains and storage vessels discovered at the Sheepen site appear to confirm this trade with the Empire.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/>
==Pre-Boudican Roman Town==
===Claudian Invasion===
{{Main article|Roman invasion of Britain}} {{Campaignbox Boudica's Uprising}} [[File:Claudius crop.jpg|thumb|right|The Emperor Claudius personally oversaw the Roman attack on Camulodunon. The town was renamed ''Colonia Victricensis'' in honour of his triumph, and [[Temple of Claudius, Colchester|a Temple built there to worship him]].]] The [[Catuvellauni]] king Cunobelinus, ruling from his capital at Camulodunon, had subjugated a large area of southern and eastern Britain,<ref name="Todd, M 1981">Todd, Malcolm. (1981) Roman Britain; 55BC - 400AD. Published by Fontana Paperbacks ({{ISBN|0 00 633756 2}})</ref><ref name="Wilson, Roger J 2002"/> and was called by the Roman historian [[Suetonius]] "King of the Britons".<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> Under his rule Camulodunon had replaced Verlamion as the most important settlement in pre-Roman Britain.<ref name="Wilson, Roger J 2002"/> Around 40 AD he had fallen out with his son [[Adminius]] (acting as proxy ruler of the [[Cantiaci]] tribe in his father’s name), who had fled to Rome for support.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> There he was received by [[Caligula|the Emperor Gaius]], who [[Caligula#Brittania|may have attempted an invasion of Britain]] to put Adminius on his father’s throne.<ref>Suetonius (1989) The Twelve Caesars. Published by Penguin Classics. ({{ISBN|0-14-044072-0}})</ref> After Cunobelinus’ death (c. 40 AD) his sons took power, with [[Togodumnus]] the eldest ruling the Catuvellauni homeland around Verlamion, and [[Caratacus]] ruling from Camulodunon.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> Together these brothers began expanding their influence over other British tribes, including the [[Atrebates]] of the south coast. [[Verica]], king of the Atrebates, which had branches on both sides of the [[English Channel]] and had been [[Roman client kingdoms in Britain|friends of Rome]] since [[Julius Caesar|Caesar’s conquest]],<ref>Caesar (1982) The Conquest of Gaul. Published by Penguin Classics. ({{ISBN|0-14-044433-5}})</ref> appealed to the [[Claudius|Emperor Claudius]] for aid. At the time of this appeal in 43 AD the newly enthroned Emperor Claudius was in need of a military victory in order to secure his shaky position with the [[Roman army|military]], and saw this call for help as the perfect pretext.<ref>Scarre, Chris (1997) Chronicle of the Roman Emperors. The Reign-by-Reign Record of the Rulers of Imperial Rome. Published by Thames and Hudson. ({{ISBN|0-500-05077-5}})</ref> [[Aulus Plautius]] led the four Roman legions across to Britain with Camulodunon being their main target,<ref name="Todd, M 1981"/> defeating and killing Togodumnus near the [[Thames]] and then waiting for Claudius to cross the Channel. Claudius arrived with reinforcements, including artillery and elephants,<ref>[[Cassius Dio]], ''Roman History'' [http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/Cassius_Dio/60*.html#19 60.19-22]</ref> leading the attack on Camulodunon. Caratacus fled the storming of the town, taking refuge with the [[Ordovices]] and [[Silures]] tribes in [[Wales]] and becoming a Welsh folk hero for his resistance to Rome.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> The Roman historian [[Suetonius]] and Claudius' triumphal arch state that after this battle the British kings who had been under Cunobelinus’ sons’ control surrendered without further bloodshed, Claudius accepting their submission in Camulodunon.<ref>[[Suetonius]], ''Claudius'' [http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/Suetonius/12Caesars/Claudius*.html#17 17]; [[s:Arch of Claudius|Arch of Claudius]]</ref>
===Roman Fortress and Early Town=== As the stronghold of a major tribe in the south-east, Camulodunum held strategic importance.<ref name="BBC"/> A Roman legionary fortress or ''[[castrum]]'', the first permanent legionary fortress to be built in Britain,<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> was established within the confines of Camulodunon (which was [[latinised]] as ''Camulodunum'') following the successful invasion in 43, and was home to the [[Legio XX Valeria Victrix|Twentieth Legion]].<ref name="Todd, M 1981"/> A smaller fort was built against the Iron Age earthworks close to the Gosbecks high-status farmstead, and was home to the Ala Primae Thracum ("First Wing of [[Thracians]]", a cavalry regiment) and the Cohors Primae Vangionum ("First Cohort of [[Vangiones]]", a mixed cavalry-infantry unit from [[Gaul]]).<ref name="RBStan">{{cite web |url=http://www.roman-britain.org/places/stanway.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-07-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924114318/http://www.roman-britain.org/places/stanway.htm |archivedate=24 September 2015 |df=dmy-all }} retrieved 29 July 2014</ref>
[[File:Colchester roman ornaments.jpg|thumb|left|Figurines from a child's burial, pre-60/1]] The legionary fortress was larger than a standard ''castrum'', and included a large annexe on its north-east side.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> It was protected by a large palisaded ditch and wall (Roman military ''[[Vallum]]'' and ''Fossa''), along with new earthwork ditch and rampart defences, built to supplement the existing native defences.<ref name="Wilson, Roger J 2002">Wilson, Roger J.A. (2002) A Guide to the Roman Remains in Britain (Fourth Edition). Published by Constable. ({{ISBN|1-84119-318-6}})</ref><ref name="Crummy, Philip 1992">Crummy, Philip (1992) Colchester Archaeological Report 6: Excavations at Culver Street, the Gilberd School, and other sites in Colchester 1971-85. Published by Colchester Archaeological Trust ({{ISBN|0-9503727-9-X}})</ref><ref name="Crummy, Philip 1984">Crummy, Philip (1984) Colchester Archaeological Report 3: Excavations at Lion Walk, Balkerne Lane, and Middleborough, Colchester, Essex. Published by Colchester Archaeological Trust ({{ISBN|0-9503727-4-9}})</ref> One of these was around the Sheepen site, which became the main Roman port for the fortress and later for the town, with another military river port at [[Fingringhoe]].<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> Archaeological excavations in 2008-2009 revealed that the Roman Sheepen site was more extensive than previously thought, and had a network of gravelled roads and timber-buildings, some of which contained timber-lined basements.<ref name="ColchArch2009"/> A wooden paddle for a [[coracle]] was found preserved at the site.<ref name="ColchArch2009"/> The fortress had two main metalled roads, a North-South ''[[via principalis]]'' and an East-West ''[[via praetoria]]'', as well as a ''via sagularis'' around the inside of the defensive walls.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1984"/> Along the roads leading out of the fortress settlements known as [[Vicus|vici]] developed, home to native Britons who served the Roman garrison.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> The interior of the fortress consisted of long barrack blocks able to hold groups of eighty soldiers, known as a [[Century (military unit)|Century]], with a large room for a Centurian at one end of each block.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1984"/> Larger buildings for [[Military tribune|military Tribunes]] have been excavated in the centre of the fort<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1984"/> The walls of the military buildings were built on mortared plinths called ''opus caementicium'', with wooden and [[Wattle and daub|daub walls]] faced with keyed plaster.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1984"/> Roman military equipment and weapons have been found from the fortress, including swords, armour and harness fittings.<ref name="Wilson, Roger J 2002"/>
[[File:Temple of Claudius Colchester 001.png|thumb|right|Plan of the [[Temple of Claudius, Colchester|Temple of Claudius at Colchester]].]] After the legion was withdrawn in c. 49, the legionary defences were dismantled and the fortress converted into a town, with many of the barrack blocks converted into housing.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/><ref name="cooper"/> Its official name became ''[[Colonia (Roman)|Colonia]] Victricensis'', with discharged Roman soldiers making up the population; a bronze military ''[[Roman military diploma|diplomata]]'' (document formalising a soldier's retirement, citizen rights and land rights) for a legionary soldier called ''Saturninus'' has been found at the Sheepen site.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> As a colonia (the only one in Britain at the time) its citizens held equal rights to Romans, and it was the principal city of Roman Britain.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> [[Tacitus]] wrote that the town was "a strong ''colonia'' of ex-soldiers established on conquered territory, to provide a protection against rebels and a centre for instructing the provincials in the procedures of the law".<ref name="Wilson, Roger J 2002"/> The [[Temple of Claudius, Colchester|Temple of Claudius]], the largest [[Roman temple|classical style temple]] in Britain, was built there in the 50s and was dedicated to Emperor Claudius on his death in 54.<ref name="BBC"/><ref name="cooper">[http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.aspx?compid=21969 "Iron-Age and Roman Colchester", ''A History of the County of Essex: Volume 9: The Borough of Colchester (1994): 2-18'', Janet Cooper, C R Elrington (Editors), A P Baggs, Beryl Board, Philip Crummy, Claude Dove, Shirley Durgan, N R Goose, R B Pugh, Pamela Studd, C C Thornton.. British History Online. Web. 01 June 2014]</ref> The podium, or foundation of the temple, was incorporated into the [[Colchester Castle|Norman castle]], and represents "the earliest substantial stone building of Roman date visible in the country".<ref name="Wilson, Roger J 2002"/> A monumental arch was built from [[tufa]] and [[Purbeck Marble]] at the western gate out of the town.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1984"/> Tombs lined the roads out of the town, with several belonging to military veterans giving insights into the military units stationed in Britain during the post-Conquest period, such as:
*The famous tomb of the [[Thracian]] cavalryman Longinus Sdapeze,<ref name="Toynbee, J. 1996"/> depicting a [[Thracian horseman]] on horseback with full armour, in triumph over a cowering Briton. It reads: ::::LONGINVS.SDAPEZE ::::MATYCI.F.DVPLICARIVS.ALA.PRIMA.TRACVM.PAGO ::::SARDICA.ANNO.XL.AEROR.XV ::::HEREDES.EXS.TESTAM.F.C. ::::H S E ::(Translated: Longinus Sdapeze, son of Matycus, [[Duplicarius]] of Ala Primae Thracum, from the country district of [[Sardica]], who lived for forty years, with fifteen years paid service. His heirs set this up as stipulated in his will. He lies here.)<ref name="RBStan"/>
*The tomb of the [[Centurion]] Marcus Favonius Facilis from Rome, depicting him in full [[Roman armour|military dress]], is one of the finest examples,<ref name="Wilson, Roger J 2002"/><ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/><ref name="Toynbee, J. 1996"/> and reads: ::::M.FAVONI.M.F.POL.FACI ::::LIS.C.LEG.XX.VERECVND ::::VS.ET.NOVCIVS.LIB.POSVERVNT H S E ::(Translated: For Marcus Favonius Facilis, son of Marcus, of the [[Roman voting tribes|Pollentian voting tribe]], centurion of the Twentieth Legion, Verecundus and Noucius his [[Freedmen#Ancient Rome|freedmen]] have placed [this memorial]. He lies here.)<ref name="roman-britain.org"/>
*The tomb of an [[Auxiliaries (Roman military)|Auxialiary]] from [[Gaul]]: ::::D M AR... RE... VAL... COH I VA... QVI M... EX AERE COLLATO ::(Translated: To the spirits of the departed and to Ar[...] Re[...] Val[...] of the First Cohort of Vangiones, who [...] former collector of taxes.)<ref name="RBStan"/>
*The tomb of another experienced Centurion from [[Anatolia]]: ::::...LEG I (or II) ADIVTRICIS... ...AE BIS C ... ... BIS C LEG III AVG ... C LEG XX VAL VICTORIVNDVS NICAEA IN BITHYNIA MILITAVIT ANN ... VIXIT ANN ... ... ::(Translated: [...] of Legio Primae Adiutrix [...] twice centurion [...] twice centurion of Legio Tertiae Augusta [...] centurion of Legio Vicesimae Valeria, Victoriundus, from [[Nicaea]] in [[Bithynia]], with [...] years military service who lived for [...] years [...])<ref name="roman-britain.org"/>
By 60-61 the population may have been as high as 30,000.<ref name="google2">{{cite book|title=A History of England in 100 Places: From Stonehenge to the Gherkin|author=Norwich, J.J.|date=2011|publisher=Hodder & Stoughton|isbn=9781848546080|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=37XQ87lOcXMC|accessdate=25 October 2014}}</ref>
===Iceni Revolt=== {{Main article|Battle of Camulodunum}} [[File:Roman emperor head.jpg|thumb|left|The head of an [[Equestrian statue]] of Claudius found in [[Suffolk]], believed to have been taken from the Temple of Claudius during Boudica's revolt.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/highlights/highlight_objects/pe_prb/b/bronze_head_of_claudius.aspx|title= Head of the Emperor Claudius|publisher=British Museum}}</ref>]] The city was the capital of the Roman province of [[Roman Britain|Britannia]], and its temple (the only classical-style temple in Britain) was the centre of the [[Imperial cult (ancient Rome)|Imperial Cult]] in the province.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> The Roman philosopher [[Seneca the Younger|Seneca]] mentioned the temple when he [[Apocolocyntosis|mocked the province for its piety towards the Deified Claudius]].<ref>Petronius – The Satyricon/Seneca – The Apocolocyntosis (1986) Published by Penguin Classics. ({{ISBN|0-14-044489-0}})</ref> The colonia was also initially home to the [[Procurator (Roman)|provincial Procurator]] of Britain. Aside from the [[Roman citizen|Roman]] population, the city and surrounding territorium was also home to a large native population. Examples of cooperation between the two groups include the Romano-British [[Stanway, Essex#Druid of Colchester|Stanway Burials mounds]]<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/><ref>http://www.camulos.com/gosbecks.htm retrieved 21 July 2014</ref> and the warrior graves of native elites from the 50s.<ref>http://www.gazette-news.co.uk/news/10677948._/ retrieved 22 July 2014</ref><ref>http://www.archaeology.org/news/1309-130918-england-warrior-catuvellauni-spears retrieved 22 July 2014</ref> These graves represent members of the native aristocracy who have been Romanised.<ref name="Strachan, David 1998"/>
However tensions arose in 60/61 when the Roman authorities used the death of [[Prasutagus]] as a pretext for seizing the [[Iceni|Iceni client state]] from his widow [[Boudica]]. The [[Boudica#Boudica's uprising|Iceni rebels]] were joined by the Trinovantes around Colonia Victricensis, who held several grudges against the Roman population of the town. These included the [[Centuriation|seizure of land for the colonia’s veteran population]], the use of labour to build the Temple of Claudius, and the sudden recall of loans given to the local elites by leading Romans (including Seneca and the Emperor), which had been needed to allow the locals to qualify for a position on the city council.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/><ref name="Tacitus">Tacitus (1876), [[s:The Annales (tacitus)/Book14#31|XIV:31]].</ref> The Procurator [[Catus Decianus]] was especially despised.<ref name="Todd, M 1981"/>
Tacitus recorded that certain ominous portents occurred in the town prior to the rebellion:
::"[...]the statue of [[Victoria (mythology)|Victory]] fell down, its back turned as though in retreat from the enemy. Women roused into frenzy chanted of approaching destruction, and declared that the cries of the barbarians had been heard in the council-chamber, that the theatre had re-echoed with shrieks, that a reflection of the ''colonia'', overthrown, had been seen in the Thames estuary. The sea appeared blood-red, and spectres of human corpses were left behind as the tide went out."<ref name="Wilson, Roger J 2002"/>
As the symbol of Roman rule in Britain the city was the first target of the rebels, with its Temple seen in British eyes as the ''arx aeternae dominationis'' ("stronghold of everlasting domination") according to Tacitus.<ref name="Wilson, Roger J 2002"/> He wrote that it was undefended by fortifications when it was attacked<ref name="Tacitus"/> with a garrison of only 200 members of the procurator's guard.<ref name="BBC"/> He wrote of a last stand at the Temple of Claudius:
:"In the attack everything was broken down and burnt. The temple where the soldiers had congregated was besieged for two days and then sacked.".<ref name="Wilson, Roger J 2002"/>
The rebels destroyed the city and slaughtered its population. Archaeologists have found layers of ash in the site of the city, suggesting that Boudica ordered her rebel army to burn the city to the ground.<ref>http://www.thecolchesterarchaeologist.co.uk/?p=13560 retrieved 21 July 2014</ref> A relief army consisting of the [[Legio IX Hispana]] led by [[Quintus Petillius Cerialis]] attempted to rescue the besieged citizens, but was [[Battle of Camulodunum|destroyed outside of the town]]. After the Romans under governor [[Gaius Suetonius Paullinus]] finally defeated the uprising, the Procurator of the province moved his seat to the newly established commercial settlement of [[Londinium]] ([[London]]).<ref>Graham Webster, ''Boudica: the British Revolt against Rome AD 60'', 1978, pp. 89-90</ref>
====Boudican Destruction Layer==== [[File:Boudica's Sprit^ Colchester - geograph.org.uk - 132842.jpg|right|thumb|Statue of Boudica in Colchester commemorating her sacking of the Roman town.]] The destruction of the early town by the rebels has left a thick layer of ash, destroyed buildings and smashed pottery and glasswork across the town centre and at the Sheepen river port site outside the NW corner of the town. The destruction layer, also found at [[Verulamium]] ([[St Albans]]) and [[Londinium]] ([[London]]), is famous for the charred preservation of artefacts and furniture,<ref name="Wilson, Roger J 2002"/> including a samian store, a glass store, beds and matresses, wall plaster, [[Roman mosaic|tessalated floors]], a few human bones with wounds and even [[Dates (fruit)|dates]] and [[plums]].<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1992"/><ref name="Crummy, Philip 1984"/><ref>http://www.thecolchesterarchaeologist.co.uk/?p=13385 retrieved 24 July 2014</ref> During excavations in 2014 at [[Williams and Griffin]] on the High Street a collection of gold and silver jewellery was discovered buried in the floor of a Roman building destroyed during the revolt.<ref name="Fenwick1">http://www.thecolchesterarchaeologist.co.uk/?p=14844 Retrieved 4 September 2014</ref> Known as the "[[Fenwick (department store)|Fenwick]] Treasure", it appears to have been buried just prior to the buildings destruction by a victim of the Boudican attack.<ref name="Fenwick1"/> The layer is important to [[historians]] as it is one of the first archaeological contexts in Britain that can be given a definitive date, as well as to [[archaeologists]] as it provides a snapshot of artifacts from 60, allowing [[Typology (archaeology)|typologies]] of finds to be tied into a historical timeline, for example in Samian production.<ref name="Bedoyere, Guy 1988"/> The rubble from the destruction was landscaped during the rebuilding of the town that took place in the years after the revolt.<ref>http://www.thecolchesterarchaeologist.co.uk/?p=13568 retrieved 22 July 2014</ref>
==''Colonia Victricensis'' in the Second and Third Centuries== [[File:ColoniaVictricensisMap02.png|thumb|right|The Roman '''Colonia Victricensis''' in its wider landscape]] Following the destruction of the Colonia and [[Suetonius Paulinus]]’ crushing of the revolt the town was rebuilt on a larger scale and flourished,<ref name="roman-britain.org"/> growing larger in size than its pre-Boudican levels (to 108 acres/45 ha)<ref name="Wilson, Roger J 2002"/> despite its loss of status to [[Londinium]], reaching its peak in the Second and 3rd centuries.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> The town's official name was ''Colonia Claudia Victricensis'' (City of Claudius’ Victory), but it was known colloquially by contemporaries (such as on the monument of Gnaeus Munatius Aurelius Bassus in Rome - ''see below'') as ''Camulodunum'' or simply ''Colonia''.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> The colonia became a large industrial centre, and was the largest, and for a short time the only, place in the province of Britannia where [[samian ware]] was produced, along with glasswork and metalwork, and a coin mint.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> Roman brick making and wine growing also took place in the area. Colonia Victricensis contained many large townhouses, with dozens of mosaics and tessellated pavements found, along with [[hypocaust]]s and sophisticated waterpipes and drains.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/><ref>http://www.thecolchesterarchaeologist.co.uk/?p=13656 retrieved 21 July 2014</ref>
The colonia is mentioned by name several times by contemporaries, including in [[Pliny the Elder|Pliny's]] [[Natural History (Pliny)|Natural History]], [[Ptolemy's Geography]], Tacitus' [[Annals (Tacitus)|Annales]], The [[Antonine Itinerary]] and the [[Ravenna Cosmography]].<ref name="roman-britain.org"/> The 2nd century tomb inscription for Gn. Munatius Bassus in Rome, which describes the name of the town and its Roman citizenship, reads:
:::GN.MVNATIVS.MF.PAL :::AVRELIVS.BASSVS :::PROCAVG :::PRAEF.FABR.PRAEF.COH.III :::SAGITTARIORVM.PRAEF.COH.ITERVM.II :::ASTVRVM.'''CENSITOR.CIVIVM''' :::'''ROMANORVM.COLONIAE.VICTRI''' :::'''CENSIS.QVAE.EST.IN.BRITTANNIA''' :::'''CAMALODVNI.'''CVRATOR :::VIAE.NOMENTANAE.PATRONVS.EIVSDEM :::MVNICIPI.FLAMEN.PERPETVS :::DVVM.VIR.ALI.POTESTATE :::AEDILIS.DICTATOR.IIII.
:(Translated: Gnaeus Munatius Aurelius Bassus, son of Marcus of the [[Roman tribe#Later tribes|Palantine Tribe]], Procurator of the Emperor, Prefect of the Armourers, Prefect of the Third Cohort of Archers, Prefect again of the Second Cohort of [[Astures|Asturians]], '''Census Officer of the Roman Citizens of Colonia Victricensis, which is in Britain at Camulodunum''', Overseer of the [[Nomentum]] Road, Patron again of the same municipality, [[Flamen|Priest]] for life, [[Aedile]] with [[Potestas|magisterial power]], Dictator four times.)<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/>
===Status=== The city was one of the few Roman settlements in Britain designated as a ''Colonia'' rather than a ''[[Municipia]]'', meaning that in legal terms it was an extension of [[Rome|the city of Rome]], not a provincial town. Its inhabitants therefore had [[Roman citizen]]ship. Of the two [[Roman province|provincial administrators]] the [[Roman senator|senatorial]] military [[Roman governor|governor]] was always located in areas of conflict,<ref>Tacitus (1986) The ''Agricola'' and the ''Germania''. Published by Penguin Classics ({{ISBN|0-14-044241-3}})</ref> whilst the civilian [[Procurator (Roman)|Procurator’s office]] had moved from Camulodunum to the new port of Londinium sometime around the Boudican Revolt.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> However the Colonia did retain the [[Sodales Augustales|Imperial cult centre and priesthood]] at the Temple of Claudius. The colonia was at the centre of a large territorium containing many [[Roman villa|villa sites]], including an important cluster around the [[River Colne, Essex|Colne estuary]].<ref name="Todd, M 1981"/>
===Walls=== [[File:Balkerne Gate, Colchester - geograph.org.uk - 189116.jpg|thumb|right|Balkerne Gate]] Following the rebuilding of the town after 60/1 new walls and a large defensive ditch were built around the colonia (the first town walls in Britain, predating other such walls in the province by at least 150 years<ref name="Wilson, Roger J 2002"/>). They were completed by 80, twenty years after the revolt.<ref name="Wilson, Roger J 2002"/><ref name="cooper"/> They were built with two external faces of alternating layers of [[Imbrex and tegula|tile]] and [[Septaria|septaria mudstone]] containing a core of septaria boulders, with a 10 ft wide and 4 ft deep foundation trench, the whole structure taking up 45,000 cubic metres of stone, tile and mortar.<ref name="Wilson, Roger J 2002"/><ref name="Strachan, David 1998"/><ref name="Crummy, Philip 1984"/> They were 2,800m long and 2.4m thick, and survive up to a height of over 6m in the 21st Century.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> Later, in around 175-200 a large earth bank was built up against the inner face of the walls.<ref name="Wilson, Roger J 2002"/> The walls had between 12 and 24 towers and six large gates.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> Balkerne Gate, in the centre of the Western section of the walls, was the main gate out of the town. It has a large fortified barbican that still stands as Britain’s largest Roman gateway, which incorporated the earlier monumental arch built before the Iceni rebellion and was flanked by two possible temples,<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1984"/> one of which may have contained the [[Venus (mythology)|Venus]] statuette found during the 1973-76 excavations.<ref>Crummy, Nina (1983) Colchester Archaeological Reports 2: The Roman small finds from Colchester 1971-9. Published by Colchester Archaeology Trust. ({{ISBN|0-9503727-3-0}})</ref> Skulls showing signs of [[decapitation]] were found in the town ditch in front of the gate, interpreted as executions on public display.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1984"/> The North wall contained two gates, the modern North Gate and Duncan’s Gate, the East wall had the modern East Gate, and the Southern wall had the modern South Gate and Head Gate.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> Drains were constructed in the wall to allow sewerage out of the colonia.<ref>http://www.camulos.com/virtual/townwall2.htm retrieved 21 July 2014</ref>
===Streets=== [[File:Roman Colchester Street Plan.gif|thumb|right|Roman streets and excavated remains of '''Colonia Victricensis''' (''Camulodunum'')]] The [[Cardo maximus]], the main North-South street, ran between North Gate and Head Gate, whilst the [[Decumanus Maximus]], the main East-West street, ran between Balkerne Gate and East Gate, and have their origins in the Legionary fortresses two main axial streets.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> They were well paved, had drainage channels and were fronted with houses and shops.<ref>http://www.thecolchesterarchaeologist.co.uk/?p=13656 retrieved 22 July 2014</ref> Many included footways, a feature that is rare in other Roman British towns.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1984"/> The rest of the colonia was gridded into around forty blocks known as [[Insula (building)|insula]], with paved streets and colonnaded paths between.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1992"/><ref name="Crummy, Philip 1984"/> As well as a system of local roads leading to settlements around the colony, Camulodunum was linked to the rest of the Province by several major roads, including [[Stane Street (Colchester)|Stane Street]], [[Camlet Way]], [[Pye Road]] and the [[Via Devana]].
===Public Buildings=== Within the town walls was located the [[Temple of Claudius, Colchester|Temple of Claudius]] in its large [[Glossary of ancient Roman religion#templum|temple precinct]] with a monumental columned arcade.<ref name="thecolchesterarchaeologist">{{cite web |url=http://www.thecolchesterarchaeologist.co.uk/?p=13840 |title=Colchester: grand Roman arcade on a monumental scale | The Colchester Archaeologist |publisher=thecolchesterarchaeologist.co.uk |accessdate=25 October 2014}}</ref><ref name="RBTemp">{{cite web |url=http://www.roman-britain.org/places/colchester_temples.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-06-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140603222036/http://www.roman-britain.org/places/colchester_temples.htm |archivedate=3 June 2014 |df=dmy-all }} retrieved 20 July 2014</ref> Parts of the temple precinct wall are still visible to the NW of the present castle, jutting out from beneath the [[Normans|Norman]] bailey rampart.<ref name="Wilson, Roger J 2002"/> The front of the precinct wall consisted of a large columned arcade screen extending the full width of the frontage.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> At the centre of this arcade stood the entranceway to the temple precinct, which took the form of a tufa-faced monumental arch that at 8 m wide was about 2 m wider than the one at the Eastern entrance to the town, which had been incorporated into Balkerne Gate.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/>
To the west of the temple on the modern Maidenburgh Street was a 3,000 seat capacity [[Roman theatre (structure)|Roman theatre]], which now has the Norman chapel of [[St Helena]] built into the corner of it,<ref name="Wilson, Roger J 2002"/> currently open to public viewing.<ref name="Wilson, Roger J 2002"/><ref name="Crummy, Philip 1992"/> Opposite the Temple, on the south side of the Decumanus Maximus, the remains of a possible [[Basilica]] have been identified.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> At least seven [[Romano-Celtic Temple|Romano-Celtic temples]] have been identified at Camulodunum,<ref name="cooper"/> with the largest located at the [[Colchester#Gosbecks Archaeological Park|Gosbecks area]] to the south of the town, built within the site of a former Iron-Age enclosure.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/>
A large portico with an eastern entrance ran all the way around the outside of the site, with a solid outer wall, a row of columns down the centre of the portico and a second row of columns around the inner side.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> In all there were about 260 columns placed 2 m apart, and reaching a height of at least 5 m.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> The portico ran around the outside of a deep, Iron-Age enclosure ditch, which separated the portico from the central space in the middle of the site. This central space contained a large Romano-Celtic temple, which stood off-centre, leading to suggestions that something else stood at the heart of the religious complex.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/>
Next to the Gosbecks temple stood a second 5,000 seat theatre, Britain’s largest at 82 m in diameter.<ref name="Wilson, Roger J 2002"/><ref name="Strachan, David 1998"/> A group of four Romano-Celtic temples stood at the Sheepen industrial site, one of which was dedicated to [[Jupiter (mythology)|Jupiter]].<ref>http://www.thecolchesterarchaeologist.co.uk/?p=15908 retrieved 30 October 2014</ref> ''Temple I'' at the Sheepen site was found to be enclosed by a large, buttressed precinct wall during excavations in 1935 and 2014.<ref>http://www.thecolchesterarchaeologist.co.uk/?p=16086 Retrieved 7 November 2014</ref>
In 2005, the [[Circus (building)#row-Camulodunum|only known Roman circus in Britain]] was discovered on the southern outskirts of the colonia.<ref>http://www.thecolchesterarchaeologist.co.uk/?p=7882 retrieved 21 July 2014</ref> It is about 450 metres long, with eight starting-gates, and it was built in the early 2nd century.<ref name="ColcArchCirc1">{{cite web|url=http://www.thecolchesterarchaeologist.co.uk/?p=13904|title=Circus Maximus games | The Colchester Archaeologist|publisher=thecolchesterarchaeologist.co.uk|accessdate=25 October 2014}}</ref> It could accommodate at least 8,000 spectators and maybe up to as many as double that.<ref name="ColcArchCirc1"/> The structure’s gates are being opened to the public.<ref>http://www.thecolchesterarchaeologist.co.uk/?p=13470 retrieved 21 July 2014</ref>
Several temples and religious monuments in and around the colonia have evidence for the deity honoured by them: * A statue of [[Venus (mythology)|Venus]] was found in the vicinity of the temple outside of the Balkerne Gate.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/>
* A statue of [[Mercury (mythology)|Mercury]] was found at the site of the Gosbecks temple.<ref name="cooper"/>
