*The Temple at the [[Colchester Royal Grammar School]] has several plaques dedicated to [[Silvanus (mythology)|Silvanus]],<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> including: ::::DEO SILVANO CALLIRIO D CINTVSMVS AERARIVS VSLM ::(Translated: To the god Silvanus Callirius, Decimus Cintusmus, coppersmith, willingly and deservedly fulfilled his vow.)<ref name="RBTemp"/>
::::DEO SILVANO HERMES VSLM ::(Translated: To the god Silvanus, Hermes willingly and deservedly fulfilled his vow.)<ref name="RBTemp"/>
* The largest of the four temples at the Sheepen site has a plaque dedicated to [[Jupiter (mythology)|Jupiter]]: ::::P.ORANIVS ::::FACILLIS.IOVI ::::SIGILLUM.EX.TESTA ::(Translated: Publius Oranius Facilis gave a statue to Jove under the terms of his will)<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/>
* An altar to the SW of the town dedicated to the [[Suleviae]]: ::::MATRIBVS SVLEVIS SIMILIS ATTI F CI CANT VSLM ::(Translated: To the Sulevi mothers, Similis the son of Attius, of the [[Durovernum Cantiacorum|Civitas Cantiacorum]], willingly and deservedly fulfills his vow.)<ref name="roman-britain.org"/>
* A Bronze plaque dedicated sometime between 222–235 CE by a [[Roman Syria|Syrian]] to [[Mars (mythology)|Mars]] and the [[Alexander Severus|Emperor Imperator Caesar Marcus Aurelius Severus]], himself a Syrian: ::::DEO MARTI MEDOCIO CAMPESIVM ET VICTORIE ALEXANDRI PII FELICIS AVGVSTI NOSI DONVM LOSSIO VEDA DE SVO POSVIT NEPOS VEPOGENI CALEDO ::(Translated: To the god of the battlefields Mars Medocius, and to the victory of [Imperator Caesar Marcus Aurelius Severus] Alexander Pius Felix Augustus, Lossius Veda the grandson of Vepogenus Caledos, placed [this] offering out of his own [funds].)<ref name="roman-britain.org"/>
* A monument, built by a local artisan Maronius, was dedicated to the "Numinibus Augusti" ([[Genius (mythology)#Imperial genii|Spirits of the Emperor]]) and Mercury: ::::NVMINIB AVG ET MERCV DEO ANDESCOCI VOVCO IMILCO AESVRILINI LIBERTVS ARAM OPERE MARONIO D S D ::(Translated: To the Spirits of the Emperor and the God Mercury, Andescoci Vouco Imilco Aesurilini, freedman, [dedicates] this altar, the work of Maronius, donated out of his own [funds].)<ref name="roman-britain.org"/>
Marble from many of these public structures has been found, including [[Purbeck Marble]] and ''giallo antico'' (a rare yellow marble from [[Tunisia]]),<ref name="Wilson, Roger J 2002"/> as well as statutes, inscriptions and plaques.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/>
Several other public buildings have been postulated for which evidence is so far lacking, for example: * Depictions on pottery, glasswork, and wall plaster from the colonia of [[Roman gladiators|gladiators]] has been suggested as evidence that the town could have possessed an [[Roman amphitheatre|amphitheatre]].<ref name="Wilson, Roger J 2002"/><ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> * A mound called "The Mount", which formerly stood in the [[St. John's Abbey, Colchester|Abbey grounds]], was once thought to have been part of a Roman burial mound,<ref name="Crummy 1981"/> although after the discovery of the Roman Circus just to the south of where it once stood, there have been suggestions by Colchester Archaeological Trust that it could have been the remnants of an amphitheatre.<ref name="ColchArch2011"/>
===Water Management=== The town's streets and walls feature many brick built drains, including several large examples in Castle Park and near [[St Botolph's Priory]].<ref name="Wilson, Roger J 2002"/> As well as drains the colonia also possessed pipes for bringing pressurised water into the settlement. At the excavations at Balkerne Lane four lines of hollow wooden pipes, joined with iron collars were found bringing water from nearby springs, as well as evidence of a possible [[Roman aqueduct|raised wooden aqueduct]] which may have been briefly in existence next to Balkerne Gate.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1984"/> Further pipes have been discovered across the town.<ref>http://www.thecolchesterarchaeologist.co.uk/?p=14116 Retrieved 5 August 2014</ref> The water would have been pressurised in reservoirs; it has been argued by archaeologist Philip Crummy that the pipes would have been fed by a ''castellum divisiorum'', a water tower with multiple outlets, and that in order to get water to where the pipes at Balkerne Lane were found some form of aqueduct or water-lifting wheel would have been need to bring it from springs West of the town.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1984"/> Within the town, a complicated system of chambers, water pipes and slots for possible water-wheels was found in Castle Park that were once described as a [[Mithraeum]] but that has now been reinterpreted as a reservoir system. A large overflow drain ran from the structure down to a culvert near Duncan's Gate where the excess water exited the town into the River Colne.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> Timber framed wells have also been discovered, and there are at least nine springs located within the walls of Camulodunum.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1984"/><ref name="Crummy, Nina 1993">Crummy, Nina; Crummy, Philip; and Crossan, Carl (1993) Colchester Archaeological Report 9: Excavations of Roman and later cemeteries, churches and monastic sites in Colchester, 1971-88. Published by Colchester Archaeological Trust ({{ISBN|1-897719-01-9}})</ref> Private baths have been found at some sites, but as yet no [[Roman bath|public baths]] have been positively identified.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1984"/>
===Houses=== [[File:Colchester mosaic.jpg|thumb|right|Roman Mosaic found at the Middleborough House, Colchester]] Many houses have been found in the colonia during archaeological excavations. Stone founded buildings largely replaced timber ones in the course of the 2nd century, while average house size tended to increase in size up to a peak at around 250.<ref name="Faulkner, Neil 1994"/> They have painted plaster walls and tiled roofs, many with tessellated mosaic floors, [[Hypocaust|hypocaust systems]], private baths and courtyards.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1992"/><ref name="Crummy, Philip 1984"/> Latrine pits, with examples well over a metre deep, have been discovered next to some of the houses.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1992"/> Large houses were also found in the extramural suburbs outside of the town walls, with the Middleborough House beneath the old Cattle Market being the largest, containing many rooms, mosaics and basements.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1984"/> The Beryfield mosaic (of 180/200) from the SE corner of the colonia is the best preserved of the more than 50 mosaics found in the town.<ref name="Wilson, Roger J 2002"/>
===Cemeteries===
[[File:Colchester sphinx.jpg|thumb|right|Roman [[sphinx]] sculpture from a tomb found in Colchester]]
In keeping with [[Roman funerals and burial|Roman burial customs]] the cemeteries for adults of the colonia in the First, Second and Third centuries are all located outside of the walls along the main roads out of the town,<ref name="Crummy, Nina 1993"/> with infants and neo-natals buried within the walls.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1984"/> The cemeteries, some of which are walled, initially contained [[Cremation|cremation burials]], with ashes placed within jars and urns depicting human faces or glass vessels; these jars were sometimes buried in "boxes" made from ceramic tiles and hypocaust flue blocks to protect the vessel.<ref name="Toynbee, J. 1996">Toynbee, J.M.C. (1996) Death and Burial in the Roman World. Published by Thames and Hudson. ({{ISBN|0-8018-5507-1}})</ref><ref name="Bedoyere, G 2000"/> Some cremation pots have graffito on them, with PVERORVA ("remains of the boys") scratched on one,<ref name="Bedoyere, G 2000"/> as do some glass vessels, such as one found with CN.A.ING.A.V.M. scratched on it (presumably the initials of the interred ashes).<ref name="Allen, Denise 1998"/> Later (post-c. 260) burials are [[inhumations]],<ref name="cooper"/> some in lead coffins decorated with patterns and images of scallop shells,<ref name="Crummy, Nina 1993"/> and some with wooden superstructures above and around them.<ref>http://www.archaeology.co.uk/articles/news/remarkable-ringfenced-burials-from-roman-colchester.htm retrieved 22 July 2014</ref> Examples of ''bustum'' burials (funerary pyre that is then covered with a mound) have been found, which are rare outside of Italy.<ref>http://www.thecolchesterarchaeologist.co.uk/?p=3304 retrieved 22 July 2014</ref> Elaborate grave goods accompanied some of the burials.<ref>http://www.thecolchesterarchaeologist.co.uk/?p=5392 retrieved 22 July 2014</ref> Many fragments of carved tombstones have been found in the cemeteries outside of the town,<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> with several being near complete such as the "Colchester Sphinx".<ref name="Wilson, Roger J 2002"/> Some of the inscriptions on the tombs are almost fully intact, including:
* The tomb of a Roman [[Eques (ancient Rome)|Eques]]: ::::...OS... ... MACRI... ... VS EQ R VIX AN XX V FRONTINA CONIVNX ET FLOR COGITATVS ET FLOR FIDELIS FECERVNT ::(Translated: [...] Macri[nus] [Flor]us, a knight of Rome, who lived for twenty-five years, Frontina his wife, with Florus Cogitatus and Florus Fidelis, have made [this memorial].)<ref name="roman-britain.org"/> * The tomb of a young man: ::::D M IN HOC TVMVLO TEGVNTVR OSSA VENERABILIS IVVENIS ... CVNCTI MVCIANVM ... ERVNT SER ... ... VN ... ::(Translated: To the spirits of the departed, within this mound are being protected the bones of the honourable young man [...] Cunctius Muciana [...] they are overthrowing slavery [...])<ref name="roman-britain.org"/>
Other funerary monuments include the large tower-like ossuary containing the remains of cremated individuals and [[birds of prey]], which was found at the junction between the road to London and the road to Gosbecks beneath the modern Colchester Royal Grammar School.<ref>http://www.thecolchesterarchaeologist.co.uk/?p=2977 retrieved 22 July 2014</ref>
===Industry and economy===
====Pottery production====
Camulodunum was a centre for pottery production, peaking at around 200,<ref name="Faulkner, Neil 1994"/> and over 40 kilns have been in the town, including those found in the northern suburbs of the colonia around Middleborough<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1984"/> and a large group at Warren Fields and Oak Drive on the southern outskirts of the Sheepen site.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1984"/> Many of the kilns are of the oval "Colchester type", whilst tile kilns have larger rectangular chambers.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1984"/> Camulodunum produced many types of pottery, including [[Terra sigillata|decorated Samian pottery]],<ref>http://www.thecolchesterarchaeologist.co.uk/?p=13052 retrieved 22 July 2014</ref> [[mortaria]], buff wares,<ref>Swan, Vivien G. (1988) Pottery in Roman Britain. Published by Shire Publishing LTD ({{ISBN|0 85263 912 0}})</ref> single-handled ring-necked flagons,<ref name="Bedoyere, G 2000">Bédoyère, Guy de la (2000) Roman Pottery in Britain. Published by Shire Publishing LTD ({{ISBN|0 7478 0469 9}})</ref> and, until c. 250, colour-coated wares.<ref name="Bedoyere, G 2000"/> In the late 1st century [[amphorae]], called "Camulodunum Carrots" for their shape and colour, were made in the colonia, and are found in thin numbers across Britain.<ref name="Bedoyere, G 2000"/> The Samian industry, copying the East Gaullish style, was active for a time in Camulodunum from 160 to about 200,<ref name="Bedoyere, Guy 1988"/> with the names of several individual Samian potters identified as working in the colonia.<ref name="Bedoyere, G 2000"/> Over 400 fragments of Samian moulds for producing the decorated pottery have been uncovered in the town,<ref name="Bedoyere, Guy 1988">Bédoyère, Guy de la (1988) Samian Ware in Britain. Published by Shire Publications LTD. ({{ISBN|0 85263 930 9}})</ref> including 37 complete examples.<ref name="Bedoyere, G 2000"/> A well-preserved Samian kiln was excavated by archaeologist M.R. Hull near Middleborough, just outside North Gate. It was 8 ft wide, with a 5m flue under a large circular kiln chamber, and had a complex system of ceramic pipes and tubes for regulating the oxidisation of the pottery to produce its distinctive red colour.<ref name="Bedoyere, Guy 1988"/> Several of the potters operating in Camulodunum in the First, Second and Third centuries are identified as immigrants from the Rhine Valley and East Gaul, including the Samian potter ''Minuso'' from [[Trier]] who also operated in other British towns,<ref name="Bedoyere, Guy 1988"/> ''Miccio'',<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> the mortaria potter ''G. Attius Marinus'' and several men called ''Sextus Valerius''.<ref name="Todd, M 1981"/><ref name="Bedoyere, Guy 1988"/> Pottery made in Camulodunum can be found across the [[East of England]], and as far away as [[Eboracum]].<ref>Monaghan, Jason (1997) Roman Pottery from York. Published by York Archaeological Trust ({{ISBN|1 872414 83 4}})</ref> One of the most famous examples of locally made pottery is the "Colchester Vase" (c. 200), which depicts combat between gladiators called Memnon and Valentinus.<ref name="Wilson, Roger J 2002"/>
====Other Activities====
[[File:Britannica Drinking Vessels 1.jpg|thumb|right|Glass vessel found in Colchester depicting chariot racing]]
As well as pottery, ceramics produced in Camulodunum also include a large tile industry, oil lamps and figurines.<ref name="Bedoyere, G 2000"/> The colonia was also a major centre of glass production,<ref name="McWhirr, Alan 1988"/><ref>http://www.cat.essex.ac.uk/reports/CAR-report-0008{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Retrieved 22 July 2014</ref> and glass moulds (including a complete example) have been discovered in the town.<ref name="Allen, Denise 1998">Allen, Denise (1998) Roman Glass in Britain. Published by Shire Archaeology LTD. ({{ISBN|0-7478-0373-0}})</ref> Glass was produced throughout the Roman period of Camulodunum, including in the late 4th century,<ref name="Allen, Denise 1998"/> and glass-making waste was discovered at Culver Street from the mid-1st century.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1992"/> Bone carving for ornamentation,<ref name="Crummy, Nina 1993"/> metal working and jewellery making<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> were also practiced, and a coin mint<ref name="Todd, M 1981"/> operated in the colonia. Archaeological excavations suggest that the period between 150 and 250 saw the largest number of active workshops in the colonia.<ref name="Faulkner, Neil 1994"/> The town was at the centre of a largely rural economy,<ref name="cooper"/> with archaeological evidence of agricultural buildings in the colonia including the large buttressed tower granary found in the Southern part of the town, in use for much of the 2nd century, with a nearby corn-drying oven.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1992"/> Many ovens have been located in excavations around the town.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/><ref name="Crummy, Philip 1992"/> A system of [[watermill]]s appears to have operated along Salary Brook near [[Ardleigh]] to the north of the settlement,<ref>Spain, R. J. (1984) ‘Romano-British watermills’, Archaeologia Cantiana, 100, 101-28.</ref> and other watermills may have operated on the Colne at the modern site of Middle Mill in Castle Park.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> [[Oysters]] from the Colne Estuary and Mersea Island have been an important food source throughout much of Colchester's history, and large dumps (some 0.5m thick) of oyster shells have been found at Balkerne Hill from the Roman period,<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/><ref name="Crummy, Philip 1984"/> along with [[mussels]], [[whelks]], [[Cockle (bivalve)|cockles]], carpet shells, [[Common periwinkle|winkle]] and [[scallop]]; fish imported from the River Colne and coast are represented by [[herring]], [[plaice]], [[flounder]], [[eel]], [[Smelt (fish)|smelt]], [[cod]], [[haddock]], [[Sea robin|gurnard]], [[Mullet (fish)|mullet]], [[dragonet]], dab, and [[Sole (fish)|sole]].<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1992"/> As well as the Sheepen river port, [[Roman road]]s lead to [[Mistley]] on the [[Essex]] bank of the [[River Stour, Suffolk|River Stour]] and to a cluster of Roman-era buildings at [[West Mersea]], both of which may also have possessed ports for the colonia.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> Imports of dates, wine (including [[Falernian wine]]), olive oil, [[jet (mineral)|jet]], [[marble]] and other goods from across the Roman Empire have been found in Colchester,<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> including a locally made amphora with an inscription suggesting that it held North African palm-tree fruit products.<ref name="Bedoyere, G 2000"/> The trade in salt from local Red Hills also appears to have continued on from the Iron Age in the Roman period, but with more sophisticated evaporation kilns.<ref name="Fawn, A 1990">Fawn, A.J.; Evans, K.A.; McMaster, I.;Davies, G.M.R. (1990) The Red Hills of Essex. Published by Colchester Archaeological Group. ({{ISBN|0 9503905 1 8}})</ref> Small numbers of tiles were imported from [[Eccles, Kent|Eccles]] in [[Kent]] by Roman settlements in South-East Britain, including Camulodunum, for a brief time in the First Century, as was Kentish Ragstone for building.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1992"/>
==Late Roman Town== The late 3rd century and 4th centuries saw a series of crises in the Empire, including the breakaway [[Gallic Empire]] (of which Britain was a part), and raids by [[Saxon]] pirates, both of which lead to the creation of the [[Saxon Shore|Saxon Shore forts]] along the East coast of Britain.<ref name="cooper"/> The fort at [[Othona]] overlooking the confluence of the [[River Blackwater, Essex|Blackwater]] and Colne estuaries, and two more at the mouth of the [[River Colne, Essex|river into the colonia]] were built to protect the town.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/><ref name="Strachan, David 1998"/> Balkerne Gate and Duncan’s Gate were both blocked up in this period, with the later showing signs of being attacked.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> The extramural suburbs outside of Balkerne Gate had gone by 300<ref name="cooper"/> and were replaced by cultivation beds.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1987"/> The re-cutting of the town ditch in front of the newly blocked Balkerne Gate in 275-300 involved destroying the water pipes which entered the colonia through the gate. However a small portal in the gateway may have been opened up later.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1987">Crummy, Philip (1987) The Coins as Dating Evidence. In Crummy, N. (ed.) Colchester Archaeological Report 4: The Coins from Excavations in Colchester 1971-9. Published by Colchester Archaeological Trust</ref> The town ditch began to silt up from c. 400 onwards.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1987"/> The troubles of the late 3rd century saw the burial of several [[coin hoard]]s around the town, including a hoard of 1,247 coins found in a grey-ware pot at Hyderabad Barracks.<ref name="ColchArch2011"/> [[File:The Roman Empire ca 400 AD.png|thumb|right|upright=1.35|The location of Camulodunum within the Late Roman Empire, c. 400]] As with many towns in the Empire, the colonia shrunk in size in the 4th century but continued to function as an important town.<ref name="Faulkner, Neil 1994">Faulkner, Neil. (1994) Late Roman Colchester, In Oxford Journal of Archaeology 13(1)</ref> Although houses tended to shrink in size, with 75% of the large townhouses being replaced by smaller buildings by c. 350,<ref name="Faulkner, Neil 1994"/> in the period 275 to 325 a weak "building boom" (the "[[Constantine the Great|Constantinian]] renaissance") occurred in the town, with new houses being built and old ones reshaped.<ref name="Faulkner, Neil 1994"/> Many of the towns mosaics date from this period, including the famous Lion Walk mosaic.<ref name="Wilson, Roger J 2002"/> Late Roman robber trenches have been found at some sites for removing and salvaging tessalated floors and tiles for reuse in later houses.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1992"/><ref name="Crummy, Philip 1984"/> The pottery industry in the town had declined significantly by 300,<ref name="Faulkner, Neil 1994"/> but the 4th century did see an increase in the bone-working industry for making furniture and jewellery,<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1992"/> and evidence of blown glass making has also been found.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1992"/> Large areas of the Southern part of the town were given over to agriculture.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1992"/>
Despite the scaling down of private buildings an increase in the size and grandeur of public buildings occurs in the period 275-400.<ref name="Faulkner, Neil 1994"/> The Temple of Claudius and its associated ''[[temenos]]'' buildings were reconstructed in the early-4th century, along with the possible forum-basilica building to the south of it.<ref name="Drury, P 1984">Drury, P.J, (1984) The Temple of Claudius Reconsidered. Britannia XV, 7-50</ref> The Temple appears to have had a large apsidal hall built across the front of the podium steps, with numismatic dating evidence taking the date of the building up to at least 395.<ref name="Drury, P 1984"/> A large hall at the Culver Street site, dated 275-325 to c. 400, may have been a large centralised storage barn for taxes paid in kind with grain.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1992"/><ref name="Faulkner, Neil 1994"/>
Although the Gosbecks Theatre had been demolished by the 3rd century, the theatre at Maidenburgh Street may still have been in use throughout the 4th century.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1982">Crummy, Philip (1982) The Roman Theatre at Colchester. "Britannia XIII", 299-302</ref> The sunken chambers of the water reservoir system found in Castle Park appear to have become blocked up with debris and dumped rubbish in the 4th century and had gone out of use.<ref name="Hull, M 1958">Hull, M.R. 1958 Roman Colchester. Oxford Society of Antiquities</ref><ref name="Crummy, Philip 1980">Crummy, Philip (1980). The Temples of Roman Colchester. In Rodwell, W (ed.) Temples, Churches and Religion: Recent Research in Roman Britain. (Oxford, British Archaeological Report 77(i))</ref> The Roman chariot circus was also demolished during the late 4th century.<ref>http://www.thecolchesterarchaeologist.co.uk/?p=16088 Retrieved 8 November 2014</ref> Increases in the number of [[Coin clipping|clipped coins]] from the 4th century have been interpreted as a breakdown in the Roman monetary economy,<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> with most new Bronze coins ceasing to be introduced in the town c. 395 and silver coins in 402 (however these coins may have remained in circulation long after being minted).<ref name="Faulkner, Neil 1994"/> For example, the coin sequence at the Butt Road church goes up to around 425, 14 years after Roman rule ended in the province.<ref name="Faulkner, Neil 1994"/>
[[Late Roman military]] equipment has been discovered in the town,<ref name="Crummy 1981"/> including an official ''[[cingulum militare]]'' belt buckle made in [[Pannonia (Roman province)|Pannonia]] for Roman frontier units.<ref name="Crummy 1981"/> Alongside Roman military equipment 4th and early 5th century [[Germanic peoples#Warfare|Germanic]] weaponry has been found alongside Germanic domestic objects in the Late Roman town, which has been interpreted by archaeologist Philip Crummy as perhaps representing Saxon ''[[foederati]]'' mercenaries living and settling in the town during this period, several decades before the [[Adventus Saxonum|Saxon migrations]] of the mid to late 5th century.<ref name="Crummy 1981"/>
===Christianity in the Late Roman Town=== {{See also|Christianity in the 4th century}} During this period the [[Late Roman Empire|late Roman]] church at Butt Road<ref name="cooper"/> just outside the town walls was built with its associated cemetery containing over 650 graves (some containing fragments of [[Sino-Roman relations|Chinese silk]]), and may be one of the earliest churches in Britain.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/><ref name="Crummy, Nina 1993"/> A strong numismatic chronology has been obtained from the over 500 coins found at the site, and puts its date from 320 to c.425.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1987"/> Five of the extramural pagan Romano-British Temples were abandoned in c.300, whilst ''Temple II'' at Sheepen was rebuilt in 350 and continued in existence until c. 375.<ref name="Hull, M 1958"/><ref name="Crummy, Philip 1980"/> ''Temple X'' outside of the Balkerne Gate had its ambulatory demolished in 325-50 leaving just its [[Cella]], perhaps repurposed as a Christian temple.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1984"/> A nearby shrine may also have survived into the late 4th century.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1984"/> Several other possible churches or Christian buildings have been postulated, such as ''Building 127'' at Culver Street and possible Roman remains beneath St Helena’s Chapel, St Nicholas Church and Roman "vaults" beneath [[St Botolph's Priory]] which might be a late-Roman [[Martyrium (architecture)|Martyrium]], although over interpretations include a bath-house.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1980"/> The Temple of Claudius, which underwent large-scale structural additions in the 4th century, may also have been repurposed as a Christian church, as a [[Chi Rho]] symbol carved on a piece of Roman pottery found in the vicinity of the ''temenos''.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> Further Roman Christian objects found in the town include a candlestick from Balkerne Lane inscribed with an [[IX monogram|Iota Chi]] symbol and a bronze spoon with [[Eternal life (Christianity)|AETERNVS VITA]] written on it.<ref name="Crummy, Nina 1993"/><ref name="Toynbee, J 1953"/> Three British Bishops attended the [[Council of Arles (314)]], one from London, one from York and a third from a place whose first word is ''Colonia'' but whose second word is too corrupted to make out with any certainty, but has been interpreted as something like ''Camulodensium'' (although [[Lincoln, England|Lincoln]] and [[Gloucester]] are other possible candidates).<ref name="Crummy, Nina 1993"/><ref name="Toynbee, J 1953">Toynbee, JMC (1953)'Christianity in Roman Britain' in Journal of Brit. Arch. Ass. 16 (3rd Series)</ref>
==Sub-Roman Period== {{Main article|Sub-Roman Britain}}
The [[Honorius (emperor)#Stilicho and the defence of Italy|formal collapse of Roman administration in the province]] occurred in the years 409-411. Activity in the 5th century continued in Camulodunum at a much reduced level,<ref name="Faulkner, Neil 1994"/> with evidence of at the Butt Road site showing that it briefly carrying on into the early 5th century.<ref name="Crummy, Nina 1993"/> Several burials within the towns walls have been dated to the 5th century. These include two burials discovered at East Hill House in 1983, which have been surgically decapitated (in a fashion found in both [[Celts|Pre-Roman]] and some early pagan-Saxon burial practices),<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/><ref name="cooper"/> and other burials cut into the 4th century barn at Culver Street.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> A skeleton of a young woman found stretched out on a Roman mosaic floor at Beryfield, within the SE corner of the walled town, was initially interpreted as a victim of a Saxon attack on the Sub-Roman town; however, it is now believed that the burial is a post-Roman grave cut down to the hard floor surface (the name ''Beryfield'' means "burial field", a reference to the Medieval graveyards in the area).<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> Burials of men armed with Germanic weaponry have also been found outside of the town walls, and might be the graves of [[Saxon]] ''[[foederati]]'' or Saxon settlers.<ref>http://www.thecolchesterarchaeologist.co.uk/?p=1154 retrieved 9 September 2014</ref> Post-Roman/early Saxon burials from the 5th, 6th and 7th centuries, some buried with weapons, have been found outside of the walls in the areas of former Roman cemeteries, suggesting a continuity of practice.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> A study by archaeologist Henry Laver concluded that all of the Roman cemeteries around Colchester contain later burials dating to the early Saxon period.<ref name="Crummy 1981">Crummy, Philip (1981). Colchester Archaeological Report 1/CBA Research Report 39: Aspects of Anglo-Saxon and Norman Colchester. Published by Colchester Archaeological Trust and the [[Council for British Archaeology]]. ({{ISBN|0 90678006 3}})</ref> Excavations of the former [[Colchester Garrison|Goojerat and Hyderabad Barracks]] in 2004 and 2010 saw the discovery of other pagan 5th century burials with Germanic weapons, nine of which were located in [[burial mound]]s surrounded by circular ditches.<ref name="ColchArch2011">The Colchester Archaeologist. Issue no. 24. (2011). (ISSN 0952-0988)</ref> As well as burials, coin hoards from the late Fourth and early Fifth centuries have been found, including a hoard minted in the reign of [[Constantine III (Western Roman Emperor)|Constantine III]] (reigned 407-411) from Artillery Folly, that are heavily clipped; this clipping must have occurred in the years after they were minted and so would have happened in the 400s (decade).<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/><ref name="cooper"/> Scattered structures have also been excavated by archaeologists, such as a mid-5th century dwelling at Lion Walk,<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1984"/> as well as 5th century loam weights and cruciform-broaches found across the town.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> At the Culver Street site a thin layer of early Saxon pottery was discovered along with two dwellings.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1992"/> Other circumstantial evidence of activity includes large post-Roman rubbish dumps, which suggest nearby occupation.<ref name="Faulkner, Neil 1994"/> Excavations at Guildford Road Estate have uncovered a Germanic-style brooch, dated to around the 420s, associated with a group of beads from a necklace, also dated to sometime between 400 and 440.<ref name="Crummy 1981"/> The presence of Late Roman and Germanic military and domestic finds within the Late Roman and Pre-Saxon Early-Fifth Century town has been interpreted by archaeologist Philip Crummy as either the result of Saxon ''foederati'' and their families living within Camulodunum, and/or cultural influences from the continent on the local population.<ref name="Crummy 1981"/> The existence of a post-Roman entity centred on the town, sometimes linked to the legend of [[Camelot#Identifications|Camelot]], has been argued<ref name="Arthur">http://www.camulos.com/arthur/official.htm Retrieved 4 November 2014</ref><ref name="camulos">{{cite web|url=http://www.camulos.com/arthur/arthur.htm|title=King Arthur of the Britons and Camelot|publisher=camulos.com|accessdate=25 October 2014}}</ref> and was first proposed by archaeologist [[Mortimer Wheeler]].
===Roman Legacy in Saxon and Early Medieval Colchester=== [[File:Trinity Church Colchester Door.JPG|left|thumb|Saxon doorway of Trinity Church. Note the Roman tiles reused in its construction]] Later dwellings at Culver Street and artifacts from the 7th and 8th centuries are seen as evidence that the shell of the Roman town was still in use into the [[Kingdom of Essex|Saxon period]].<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/><ref name="Crummy, Philip 1992"/> The ''[[Historia Brittonum|History of the Britons]]'' traditionally ascribed to [[Nennius]] includes a list of the [[28 Cities of Britain|28 cities]] of [[Sub-Roman Britain|Britain]], including a '''[[Caer|Cair]] Colun'''<ref>[[Nennius]] ({{abbr|attrib.|Traditional attribution}}). [[Theodor Mommsen]] ({{abbr|ed.|Editor}}). [[s:la:Historia Brittonum#VI. CIVITATES BRITANNIAE|''Historia Brittonum'', VI.]] Composed after {{sc|ad}} 830. {{la icon}} Hosted at [[s:la:Main Page|Latin Wikisource]].</ref> that has been thought to indicate Colchester.<ref name=nashford>Ford, David Nash. "[http://www.britannia.com/history/ebk/articles/nenniuscities.html The 28 Cities of Britain]" at Britannia. 2000.</ref><ref name=shusher>Newman, John Henry & al. [http://www.mocavo.co.uk/Lives-of-the-English-Saints-St-Gilbert-Prior-of-Sempringham-Volume-3/527392/459 ''Lives of the English Saints: St. German, Bishop of Auxerre'', Ch. X: "Britain in 429, A. D.",<!--sic--> p. 92.] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160321234154/http://www.mocavo.co.uk/Lives-of-the-English-Saints-St-Gilbert-Prior-of-Sempringham-Volume-3/527392/459# |date=21 March 2016 }} James Toovey (London), 1844.</ref> Archaeology aside, Colchester first explicitly re-enters the ''written'' historical record again in the [[Anglo-Saxon Chronicle]] for 917, the year it was retaken from the Danes by a Saxon army led by [[Edward the Elder|King Edward the Elder]], who "restored" the borough to English rule.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> The walls of the colonia have been retained,<ref name="Crummy 1981"/> and many of the [[Medieval]] and [[Saxon architecture|Saxon]] buildings in Colchester, including the [[Colchester Castle|Castle]], [[St Botolph's Priory]], [[St John's Abbey, Colchester|St John's Abbey]], Greyfriars, [[Colchester churches#Holy Trinity|Holy Trinity church]] and many of the Norman "stone houses" were built from the vast amounts of [[Spolia|Roman debris left over in the town]].<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997">Crummy, Philip (1997) City of Victory; the story of Colchester - Britain's first Roman town. Published by Colchester Archaeological Trust ({{ISBN|1 897719 04 3}})</ref><ref>Ashdown-Hill, John (2009) Mediaeval Colchester's Lost Landmarks. Published by The Breedon Books Publishing Company Limited. ({{ISBN|978-1-85983-686-6}})</ref> Over 25,000 cubic metres of reused Roman tile and brick was used for the Castle alone.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> The quarrying of Roman rubble for building material reached a peak in the 12th and 13th Centuries.<ref name="Crummy 1981"/>
Several structures from the Saxon and Medieval period incorporated Roman structural remains within their walls and outlines.<ref name="Crummy 1981"/> The Temple of Claudius was a standing ruin until the Normans cleared the superstructure to incorporate the podium into [[Colchester Castle]] in the 11th Century.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/><ref name="Crummy 1981"/> In 2014 the discovery of marble pillars belonging to the Monumental Facade of the Temple precinct was made behind the High Street, with evidence suggesting that they were still standing until the Castle-builders knocked them over to make way for the Castle Bailey.<ref>http://www.thecolchesterarchaeologist.co.uk/?p=13902 retrieved 26 July 2014</ref> The Normans referred to the Temple as King Coel's Palace and to the barbican of Balkerne Gate as Colkyng's Castle, reflecting a myth that continued into the Medieval period, and was recorded in the ''Colchester Chronicle'' (written in the 13th or early 14th century at [[St John's Abbey, Colchester|St John's Abbey]]), that the Roman town was founded by a warlord called [[Coel Hen|Coel]]. According to the Medieval legend,<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> which garbles folk-tales and pseudo-historical events together, he was supposedly the father of [[St Helena]], who was married off to [[Flavius Valerius Constantius|Constantius]] in a bid to get the latter to lift his two-year siege of the town. Their son, [[Constantine the Great]] was then supposedly born in the town. St Helena is today the patron saint of Colchester, and the [[Coat of arms of Colchester|town's coat of arms]] depict the True Cross and crowns of the Three Kings that she is supposed to have found in [[Jerusalem]].<ref name="cooper"/> Other examples of Roman remains used in later buildings include several Medieval cellars on the High Street,<ref name="Crummy 1981"/> [[Churches in Colchester|St Nicholas Church]] (demolished in the 1950s), which was built on a Roman building and originally incorporated the remains of standing Roman walls,<ref name="Crummy 1981"/> and St Helens Chapel, which was built into the corner of the Roman theatre in the town.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/><ref name="Crummy 1981"/> A study in the late 1970s by Colchester Archaeological Trust discovered that many of the Medieval property boundaries within Colchester's town centre followed the lines of Roman street frontages and the walls of Roman buildings.<ref name="Crummy 1981"/> This was especially prominent along the High Street, where the Medieval street "frontage of the High Street between St Runwald's Church and Maidenburgh Street has fossilized the imprint of the Roman town underneath...".<ref name="Crummy 1981"/> St Runwald's Church (demolished in the 19th century) formerly stood in the centre of the High Street market just east of the current Town Hall, and was built into the corner of a junction between two Roman streets.<ref name="Crummy 1981"/> The study concluded that Roman building ruins and old street remains were in some cases used as a template for later property divisions.<ref name="Crummy 1981"/>
The name of the town and the River Colne are also a legacy of the Romans. "Colchester" (first appearing in written form in the 10th Century as ''Colencaester'' and ''Colneceastre'') is a [[Old English|Saxon]] name derived from the Latin words ''Colonia'' and ''Castra'',<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/> with the River Colne also taking its name from ''Colonia''.<ref name="Crummy, Philip 1997"/>

{{unreferenced|date=September 2010}} '''Culai Academy''' or '''Culai Academy of Classical Learning''' (徂徕书院 ''cúlái shūyuàn'') was built by the [[Northern Song]] scholar [[Shi Jie (scholar)|Shi Jie]] during the time of his mourning (1038–40). Beside the academy was the "Duyi-tang" (读易堂 ''dúyì-táng'', "Hall for Reading the Yi"), where Shi Jie, [[Sun Fu]], and Shi Jie's disciple Jiang Qian studied the [[Zuo Zhuan]] to the [[Spring and Autumn Annals]] and the [[I Ching|Book of Changes]].
It has been classed as one of the Four Great [[Academies (China)|Academies]] of the Early Song.
The academy was located on the north side of [[Mt Culai]], currently [[Tai'an]] City, [[Shandong]] province. The place is now called ''Shufang'' (書坊), meaning "library".
[[Category:Confucian education]] [[Category:Song dynasty]] [[Category:11th-century establishments in China]] [[Category:History of education in China]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in the 11th century]]

The '''Dahomean religion''' was practiced by the [[Fon people]] of the [[Dahomey]] Kingdom. The kingdom existed until 1898 in what is now the country of [[Benin]]. Slaves taken from Dahomey to the Caribbean used elements of the religion to form [[Haitian Vodou|Vodou]] and other religions of the [[Afro-Caribbean]] diaspora.<ref name="ak"/><ref name="an"/>
==''Mawu'' and ''Lisa''== [[Lisa (mythology)|Lisa]] (male) and [[Mawu]] (female), married twin siblings of [[Nana Buluku]], are the creator spirits, occasionally combined as [[Mawu-Lisa]], an androgynous spirit. Mawu-Lisa created the world and made it orderly, then made [[plant]]s, [[animal]]s, and [[human]]s; the entire process took four days. *The first day, Mawu-Lisa created the world and humanity; *The second day the earth was made suitable for human life; *On the third day, humans were given intellect, language, and the senses; *Finally, on the fourth day, mankind received the gift of technology.
==Offspring-spirits of ''Mawu'' and ''Lisa''== *[[Gbadu]] *Da and [[Gu (god)|Gu]] *[[Damballa|Dan]]

[[Bengali language|Bengali]] |religion = Hinduism |government_type = Monarchy |leader1 = |year_leader1 = |leader2 = |year_leader2 = |leader3 = |year_leader3 = |title_leader = [[Maharaja]] |legislature = |}} {{History of Bengal}} {{HistoryOfSouthAsia}} '''Deva Dynasty''' (c. 12th – 13th centuries) was a [[Hindu]] dynasty which originated in the [[Bengal]] region of the [[Indian subcontinent]]; the dynasty ruled over eastern Bengal after the [[Sena dynasty]]. The capital of the dynasty was [[Bikrampur|Chittagaung]] in present-day [[Munshiganj District]] of [[Bangladesh]]. This Hindu [[Vaishnava]] dynasty is different from an earlier Buddhist Dabnyawatti dynasty (c. 8th-9th centuries) of [[Samatata]], whose capital was Danyawatti. Four rulers of this dynasty are known from the inscriptions: Shantideva, Viradeva, Anandadeva and Bhavadeva. The rule of the Devas was indeed a period of peace, prosperity, and creative excellence, and may be designated as the "Golden Age". ==Rulers== The major sources of the history of this dynasty are the three copperplate inscriptions of Damodaradeva issued in years 1156, 1158 and 1165 of the [[Saka era]], which were his 4th, 6th and 13th [[regnal year]]s. Although there are many myths about this dynasty, none were proved with strong evidence. The first three rulers are known from the Chittagong copperplate inscription of Damodaradeva dated Saka era 1165. The first ruler of this dynasty was Purushottamadeva, who rose from the position of a village chief (''gramani''). His son Madhumathana or Madhusudanadeva was the first independent ruler of this dynasty, who assumed the title of ''nripati''. He was succeeded by his son Vasudeva and Vasudeva was succeeded by his son Damodaradeva. Damodaradeva (reigned 1231–1243) was the most powerful ruler of this dynasty. He took the title of ''Ariraja-Chanura-Madhava-Sakala-Bhupati-Chakravarti''. The inscriptional evidences show that his kingdom was extended up to the present-day [[Comilla District|Comilla]]-[[Noakhali district|Noakhali]]-[[Chittagong District|Chittagong]] region. A later ruler of this dynasty ''Ariraja-Danuja-Madhava'' [[Dasharathadeva]] extended his kingdom up to [[Bikrampur]] and made it his capital.Roy, Niharranjan (1993). ''Bangalir Itihas: Adiparba'' Calcutta: Dey's Publishing, {{ISBN|81-7079-270-3}}, pp.408-9 He issued an inscription from here.{{citation needed|date=January 2016}} [[Yahya bin Ahmad Sirhindi|Yahya bin Ahmad]] in his ''Tarikh-i-Mubarak Shahi'' mentioned that he (referred as [[Danuj Rai]] of Sonargaon by Yahya) made an alliance with [[Ghiyas ud din Balban|Ghiyas-ud-Din Balban]] in 1281.{{cite book |editor1-last=Majumdar |editor1-first=Ramesh Chandra |editor1-link=R. C. Majumdar |editor2-last=Pusalker |editor2-first=A. D. |editor3-last=Majumdar |editor3-first=A. K. |date=1960 |title=[[The History and Culture of the Indian People]] |volume=VI: The Delhi Sultanate |edition= |location=Bombay |publisher=Bharatiya Vidya Bhavan |page=622 |quote="Yahyā, the historian of the fifteenth century, mentions ... When Ghiyās-ud-din Balban proceeded to Bengal ... he sought to enter into an alliance with the Hindu king of Eastern Bengal, Rāi Danuj."}} His brother Bikramaditya Deva later moved to the eastern side of the kingdom in 1294. This is the last recorded history of this dynasty. ==See also== * [[Pala Empire]] * [[History of Bengal]] * [[History of India]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{s-start}} {{succession box | title = Bengal dynasty | years = | before = [[Sena dynasty]] | after = [[Mamluk dynasty of Delhi|Mamluk dynasty]] }} {{s-end}} [[Category:Dynasties of Bengal]] [[Category:Dynasties of India]] [[Category:Hindu dynasties]] [[Category:Historical Hindu empires]] [[Category:History of Bangladesh]] [[Category:History of Bengal]] [[Category:Medieval India]] [[Category:States and territories established in the 11th century]] {{India-hist-stub}}

{{italic title}} '''''Dialogue Between a Priest and a Dying Man''''' (original French: ''Dialogue entre un prêtre et un moribond'') is a dialogue written by the [[Marquis de Sade]] while incarcerated at the [[Château de Vincennes]] in 1782. It is one of the earliest known written works from de Sade to be dated with certainty, and was first published in 1926 together with an edition of ''[[Historiettes, Contes et Fabliaux]]'' (written originally in 1788). It was subsequently published in English in 1927 by [[Pascal Covici]] in a limited, hand-numbered edition of 650 copies. ==Plot== The work expresses the author's [[atheism]] by having a dying man (a [[libertine]]) tell a priest about what he views as the mistakes of a [[pious]] life. According to John Phillips, Emeritus Professor of French Literature and Culture at London Metropolitan University:
Of all the direct expressions of atheism in Sade's work, the ''Dialogue''... is probably the most incisive and, at the same time, the most artistically satisfying... The influence of Sade's Jesuit training in rhetorical debate is the mainspring of this brilliant dramatic essay, which, as the title suggests, is not so much theatre as philosophical dialogue. But what makes the work charming as well as persuasive is the impish humour that lies behind its characters and situation.Phillips, John (2005). ''The Marquis de Sade: a very short introduction.'' Oxford: Oxford University Press. pp.37-38. {{ISBN|0-19-280469-3}}.
However, Steven Barbone, of [[San Diego State University]] notes that:
We can postulate one of two things: Sade was entirely pleased with this manuscript and saw no reason to make any changes to it or Sade completely gave up on the dialogue and had decided to abandon it. The reason for either of these hypotheses is that the manuscript itself contains almost no trace of Sade’s editing. It is up to the reader to divine whether the “Dialogue between the Priest and a Dying Man” is Sade’s position or not. Either way, it is worth reading even in the very unlikely event that it presents a position Sade would have repudiated. (This may be the case: near the beginning of October 1788, Sade himself made a catalogue of his works, and the “Dialogue” is omitted.) de Sade, Donatien-Alphonse-François. Dialogue between a priest and a dying man. English version and introduction by Steven Barbone. ''[[Philosophy and Theology]]'', Vol. 12 (2), 2000. {{doi|10.5840/philtheol200012221}}{{rp|343}}
==Publication history== Sade completed the notebook which contains the Dialogue on 12 July 1782, while imprisoned at [[Château de Vincennes]]. He took the manuscript with him when he was transferred to the [[Bastille]] in 1784.{{rp|343}} Following the [[Storming of the Bastille]] on 14 July [[1789]], Sade's prison writings disappeared (Sade had been moved to [[Charenton (asylum)|Charenton]] on 4 July), the manuscript of the Dialogue among them. However, it survived in private collections and was sold on at auction a number of times during the nineteenth century. On 6 November 1920 it was bought by [[Maurice Heine]] at an auction at the [[Hôtel Drouot]], [[Paris]], and he oversaw its publication in France for the first time in 1926 de Sade, Donatien-Alphonse-François, Marquis. ''Dialogue entre un prêtre et un moribond, par Donatien-Alphonse-François, marquis de Sade, publié, pour la première fois, sur le manuscrit autographe inédit, avec un avant-propos et des notes, par Maurice Heine.'' Paris, Société générale d'imprimerie et d'édition (71, rue de Rennes; Stendhal et Cie), 1926. in a limited edition of 500 copies for which he wrote an introduction. The Dialogue has been republished in French several times since the 1950s,Walter, Nicolas. Translator's note. in: de Sade, Marquis. ''Dialogue between a priest and a dying man.'' London: G.W. Foote & Co. Ltd., 2001. {{ISBN|978-1-911578-03-1}} including in scholarly editions of the works of Sade edited by [[Gilbert Lely]],de Sade, Donatien-Alphonse-François. ''Oeuvres complètes.'' Edited by Gilbert Lely. 16 vols. Paris: Cercle du livre précieux, 1966-67 (the Dialogue is in vol. 14, pp.53-64) Le Brun and [[Jean-Jacques Pauvert|Pauvert]],de Sade, Donatien-Alphonse-François. ''Oeuvres complètes du marquis de Sade.'' Edited by Annie Le Brun and Jean-Jacques Pauvert. 15 vols. Paris: Pauvert, 1986-91 (the Dialogue is in vol. 1). and Michel Delon.de Sade, Donatien-Alphonse-François. ''Oeuvres.'' 3 vols. Paris: Gallimard, 1990-1998 (the Dialogue is in vol. 1, 1990, pp.1-11) ===English translations=== The first English translation was published in the United States by [[Pascal Covici]] in 1927, again in a limited edition of 650 numbered copies. The translator was [[Samuel Putnam]]. This edition was based on the first French edition and included a translation of Heine's introduction.de Sade, Marquis. ''Dialogue between a Priest and a Dying Man.'' Translated by Samuel Putnam. Chicago: P. Covici, 1927. In 1929, [[E. Haldeman-Julius|Haldeman-Julius]] published the Putnam translation as [[Little Blue Book]] #1405, under the title ''Dialogue between a priest and a dying atheist''.de Sade, Marquis. ''Dialogue between a priest and a dying atheist.'' Translated by Samuel Putnam. Girard: Haldeman-Julius. Reprint, 1929. Little Blue Book No. 1405. A version of this edition (with a short extract from Heine's introduction) was republished in 1997 by [[Chaz Bufe|Chaz Bufe's]] See Sharp Press.de Sade, Marquis. ''Dialogue between a priest and a dying atheist.'' Reprint. See Sharp Press, 1997. Further original English translations have been produced by Leonard de Saint-Yves (1953 de Sade, Marquis. ''Selected writings of de Sade.'' Translated by Leonard de Saint-Yves. London: Peter Owen, 1953/New York: British Book Centre, 1954. pp.17-29.), Paul Dinnage (1953,de Sade, Marquis. ''Marquis de Sade: an essay by Simone de Beauvoir, with selections from his writings chosen by Paul Dinnage.'' Edited by Paul Dinnage. New York: Grove Press, 1953. pp.85-89. incomplete), [[Richard Seaver]] and [[Austryn Wainhouse]] (1965.de Sade, Marquis. Dialogue between a priest and a dying man (1782). in ''The Complete Justine, Philosophy in the Bedroom, and other writings.'' Compiled and translated by Richard Seaver and Austryn Wainhouse. New York: Grove Press, 1965. (reprinted several times) For more on the Seaver/Wainhouse translations of de Sade, see Wyngaard (2013) Wyngaard, Amy S. (2013). Translating Sade: the Grove Press Editions, 1953-1968. ''The Romanic Review'', Vol. 104 (3/4), May–November, pp.313-331.), Paul J. Gillett (1966 de Sade, Marquis. ''The Complete Marquis de Sade.'' Edited and translated by Paul J. Gillett. Los Angeles: Holloway House Pub. Co., 1966. Dialogue is in Vol. 2), [[Nicolas Walter]] (1982,de Sade, Marquis. Dialogue between a priest and a dying man. Translated by Nicolas Walter. ''[[New Humanist]]'', Vol. 97 (2), Summer, 1982 reprinted 2001de Sade, Marquis. ''Dialogue between a priest and a dying man.'' Translated by Nicolas Walter. London: G.W. Foote & Co. Ltd., 2001. {{ISBN|978-1-911578-03-1}}), Margaret Crosland (1991 de Sade, Marquis. Dialogue entre un prêtre et un moribond. in Crosland, Margaret (ed.) ''The Passionate Philosopher: a Marquis de Sade reader''. London: Peter Owen, 1991. pp.19-30. {{ISBN|0-7206-0826-0}}), David Coward (1992 de Sade, Marquis. ''The Misfortunes of Virtue and Other Early Tales''. Translated with an introduction and notes by David Coward. Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1992. (the Dialogue is found at pp.149-160). [Also available in Donnachie, Ian and Lavin, Carmen (eds.) (2003). ''From enlightenment to romanticism: anthology 1''. Manchester: Manchester University Press. {{ISBN|0-7190-6671-9}}. pp.60-69.]) and Steven Barbone (2000 ). ==Legacy== The dialogue inspired a similar scene in [[Luis Buñuel]]'s film ''[[Nazarín]]'' (1959), wherein a dying woman wards off a priest while on her deathbed. Buñuel had previously adapted ''[[The 120 Days of Sodom]]'' into a scene in his earlier ''[[L'Age d'Or]]'' (1930) and would go on to feature the Marquis himself as a character in ''[[The Milky Way (1969 film)|La Voie Lactée]]'' (1969). ==External links== * [https://eupraxsofia.files.wordpress.com/2008/01/marquis-de-sade-dialog-between-a-priest-and-a-dying-man.pdf ''Dialogue Between a Priest and a Dying Man''] (Full text) * {{fr icon}} [http://www.litteratureaudio.com/livre-audio-gratuit-mp3/sade-marquis-de-trois-nouvelles.html/ ''Dialogue Between a Priest and a Dying Man'', audio version] [[Image:Speaker Icon.svg|20px]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{desade}} [[Category:Atheism publications]] [[Category:Works by the Marquis de Sade]] [[Category:1926 short stories]] [[Category:Dialogues]] [[Category:Prison writings]] [[Category:Criticism of religion]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Infobox historic site | name = Ghatotkacha Cave | image = Ghatotkach cave.jpg | caption = Ghatotkacha Cave | type = | locmapin = India | coordinates = {{Coord|20.552620|N|75.584977|E|display=title,inline}}<!-- {{Coord}} --> | location = | area = | built = | architect = | architecture = | governing_body = Archeological Survey of India }} {{BuddhasHolySites}} The '''Ghatotkach Caves''' are located 18 km to the west of [[Ajantha, Maharashtra|Ajantha]], near Jinjala village, [[India]].<ref name=AHIR /> The caves include three [[Buddhist]] [[caves]], one is a [[chaitya]] and two are [[vihara]]s. The caves were excavated in the 6th century AD, and were influenced by [[Mahayana Buddhism]].<ref name=AHIR />
The caves have an inscription from a minister of the [[Vakataka]] dynasty. The inscription is about the [[Buddha]], the [[Dhamma]] and the [[Sangha (Buddhism)|Sangha]].<ref name=AHIR>{{cite book|last=Ahir|first=D. C.|title=Buddhist sites and shrines in India : history, art, and architecture|year=2003|publisher=Sri Satguru Publ.|location=Delhi|isbn=8170307740|pages=191–192|edition=1.}}</ref>
The [[Maharashtra Tourism Development Corporation]] advises that the caves are only for the adventurous traveller as access is difficult.<ref>{{cite book|title=Vision Tourism 2020 - Aurangabad District Perspective Draft Plan|date=November 2010|publisher=Maharashtra Tourism Development Corporation|location=Aurangabad|url=http://aurangabad.nic.in/htmldocs/vision2020/10_groupnotourism.pdf|accessdate=28 June 2013}}</ref>
[[File:Ghatotkach caves.jpg|thumb|center|500px|The Ghatotkacha Caves and their environment.]]

{{Italic title|reason=[[:Category:Japanese words and phrases]]}} [[File:Izumo-shrine Haiden01.jpg|thumb|250 px|[[Izumo Taisha]]'s ''haiden'']]In [[Shinto shrine]] architecture, the {{nihongo||拝殿|'''haiden'''}} is the hall of worship or [[Oratory (worship)|oratory]]. It is generally placed in front of the shrine's main sanctuary (''[[honden]]'') and often built on a larger scale than the latter. The ''haiden'' is often connected to the ''honden'' by a ''[[Heiden (Shinto)|heiden]]'', or hall of offerings. While the ''honden'' is the place for the enshrined ''[[kami]]'' and off-limits to the general public, the ''haiden'' provides a space for ceremonies and for worshiping the ''kami''.<ref name="haiden-encycl">{{cite encyclopedia | last = Mori | first = Mizue | encyclopedia = Encyclopedia of Shinto | title = Haiden | url = http://eos.kokugakuin.ac.jp/modules/xwords/entry.php?entryID=245 | accessdate = 2009-11-16 | edition = β1.3 | date = 2005-06-02 | publisher = [[Kokugakuin University]] | location = [[Tokyo]] }}</ref><ref name="haiden-jaanus">{{cite web | url = http://www.aisf.or.jp/~jaanus/deta/h/haiden.htm | title = ''haiden'' | publisher = [[JAANUS|JAANUS - Japanese Architecture and Art Net User System]] | accessdate = 2009-11-08 }}</ref> In some cases, for example at [[Nara prefecture|Nara]]'s [[Ōmiwa Shrine]], the ''honden'' can be missing and be replaced by a patch of sacred ground.<ref name="haiden-jaanus"/> In that case, the ''haiden'' is the most important building of the complex.
